remixed_from.author: beekeeper
remixed_from.title: Minifig Golf Cart with Turning Wheels

description.text: Edit, 15 November 2012: I'm honored that the Winter 2013 Make: 3D PRINTER BUYERS GUIDE mentioned the Roll-A-Hedgehog (p20, illustrated on p2))... but I very strongly urge you NOT to use this as an infant toy unless you are paying very close attention. The body, if printed without scaling, is borderline large enough for safety. The wheels/axles, however, would definitely be choking hazards if they were to break. I've not had one break yet, but it's not impossible: that's a cross-layer feature.

Just a little hedgehog, rollin' along.  
Thanks to everyone who test printed before I had a chance to do so. With your feedback, my first print of this rolled great!  
By the way, the hedgehog profile was borrowed from a wood ramp walking hedgehog my parents brought back from a trip to the Czeck Republic. I'd like to render that printable too.

Print and play!   
I printed without acceleration, 15% fill, 0 extra shells. Less fill would probably still be plenty sturdy.  
Note that my rendering is misleading: this is not set up for dualstrusion yet. I suppose with the right software you could extract the bodies and save separately?  
Take precautions to preserve exterior surface finish: at this scale (~44mm long) there is a consistent 0.7mm gap between wheels and body. Any blobbing or such surface artifacts risks bridging that gap.  
Using the scale function to increase overall size will increase this gap proportionally... but he'll be less cute.

A simple conversion of three existing models into something usable as a D&D figurine. It was based off of a generic beetle model and I posed it on a pile of skulls model. I then added a cylindrical base and ran it through an stl repairer.

I designed this for use in my D&D campaign. It is a fairly weak enemy, but its shell can be brewed into a potion that permanently increases a character's maximum hp by one point.

Reinforcement

If this model is printed at the recommended 1"x1" base size, the antennae might be flimsy. I reinforced mine with a small layer of epoxy.

Combining

I used blender to move the models around and cut off the extra skulls on the bottom. Then I exported it as an stl file and ran it through an stl repair program.

title: Anti Z-Wobble for M8 Lead Screw - Geeetech I3 ProB (not for Anet A8)

description.text:
This is another Anti Z-Wobble accessory. I wasn't satisfied with the designs I found on thingiverse. I've tried 2 of them and it was necessary to post-process them with sand-paper or a file.
That is why I made one myself. This is for the M8-brass nut that came with your printer.
Every version works but please use V3.
V1 and V2 need support under, and these are more bulky => material waste.

V1 uses 2680 mm filament / 2pcs
V2 uses 1560 mm filament / 2pcs

V3 is the most lightweight and best at reducing Z-Wobble
ca. 840 mm filament / for both pieces with 30% infill
ca. 25-30 min print time

Here is also the Onshape link for who is interested how I designed the V3:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/13b74f353e231a472b213c9e/w/24be6bb126f6166e793852de/e/7cc0b1047f20e9ff1dfaa3b1

This is not for Anet A8 because the brass-nut must be mounted below the X-axis for this accessory to work. The two guide-feet doesn't support the weight of the X-axis.

Who also has a more bent M8-rod, I recommend the following part designed by @aurhe for the same printer: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1975163

I'm using both parts the one from @aurhe for isolating the top of the rod and the V3 of my design for the driving M8-Nut under the X-Axis sled.

I wish you happy printing without Z-Wobble

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.200

Infill:

30% or more - Rectangular

Notes:

The V1 and V2 need support, but the V3 doesn't.
The screws fit perfectly without any post-process. Use your original brass-nut and screws and there you go.

author: gonzapa

title: K40 laser cutter 4 inch exhaust port

description.text:
I print at 100 percent infill for maximum strength.
No supports. Many of the holes for the plastic nuts are designed to be tapped 1/4 20 so they may be slightly too small. Drill them out or tap them. The 4 inch silver vent hose I bought doesn't fit the fan so I made an adapter. It comes in two sizes. Use duct tape to tape the ducting. That's exactly what its designed for.

Assembly:

  1. Install inner metal air duct using original screws and nuts. Except put the nuts on the outside of the machine. GENTLY finger tighten them.

  2. Facing machine from the rear. Remove leftmost nut and install flat plate(cover.stl).

  3. Remove top nut and slide the main square vent piece(tower.stl) onto it and lightly tighten nut down with fingers. You have to put your other hand through the end of the vent and use your fingers to hold the screw in place.

  4. Repeat for the right and lower side. It can be difficult if you have large hands. I am an adult male and was able to do it but I have small trump sized hands.

  5. Install square end piece(top.stl) with glue/sealant and printed nut/bolt(quarter20nuttest3.stl).

  6. Install round vent adapter(ring.stl) with glue/sealant and printed nuts/bolts.

The entire thing was designed to use minimal amounts of plastic so if you want anything thicker/stronger open the .rsdoc file in DesignSpark Mechanical and change away.

print_settings.Notes:: I was lucky enough to get a leftover piece of granite counter top that fits over the table that my printer sits on.   This is good for two reasons:  First, it gives the table some substantial weight, and stiffness, and I do not have any vibration problems;  Secondly, when I take a hot piece of plastic off of the print bed, I press it hard against the cold granite table top, and it cools the part quickly as I flatten the part out.  Ever since I started doing this, my thin parts are more flat.

title: World Gym Account Barcode Key Tag Holder

description.text:
A friend of mine goes to World Gym. I do not.

They were telling me that the keychain tag that has the account barcode are really, really flimsy. They get damaged easily and they are expensive to have replaced.

So he asked me to create a holder for him to keep his key tag safe.

This does snap together, but I will lay odds that it will come apart at some bad time. I recommend that you super glue it closed. You could easily liberate your key tag at a later time, should the need arise.

I will work on a more reliable snap together fit.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100% linear.

Notes:

I was lucky enough to get a leftover piece of granite counter top that fits over the table that my printer sits on. This is good for two reasons: First, it gives the table some substantial weight, and stiffness, and I do not have any vibration problems; Secondly, when I take a hot piece of plastic off of the print bed, I press it hard against the cold granite table top, and it cools the part quickly as I flatten the part out. Ever since I started doing this, my thin parts are more flat.

Might want to glue it shut.

It snaps together, but I would suggest using super glue to keep it from coming apart.

What I call the cover, has the hole for the barcode to show through. The other part, I call the bottom. Carefully put super glue around the outside rim of the bottom piece. The outside rim will fit inside the cover. Squoosh it together for a minute to make sure the fit is tight and to remove any creaking.

Photocopied the tag. Traced it in Blender.

I will work on the snap together fit.

author: hopkinsju

print_settings.Notes:: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2274499

title: LED Light CR-10/CR-10s Fan Blower Mount (No Screws Needed)

description.text:
I was looking for a light that could go over my prints while printing but couldn't find anything so I decide to design my own. Also, I made it so you don't have to use any screws. It lights up your prints while your printing.

Directions:
Mount onto the 2 extra screw holes on the fan blowers.

For the LED's:
To power the LED's I cut the two wires to the cooling fan for the extruder. Then I soldered just the positive wire to the fan coolers positive wire. Next, I ran the ground wire all the way next to the control box and connected a switch to it. Then connected another wire to the switch and ran it back and connected it to the fan coolers ground wire. I plan on making a little box for the switch to fit in that can be mounted down with the screws from the spool holder.

Parts:

  • 12v LED Strip (or any LED's that use 12v, I think the fan runs off of 12v)
  • Wire
  • 1x Switch (Optional)

LED's - https://www.amazon.com/Flexible-Non-waterproof-Christmas-Decoration-Daylight/dp/B00HSF65MC/ref=sr_1_4?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1515286556&sr=1-4&keywords=led+strip

Switch - https://www.amazon.com/WGCD-Solder-Position-Panel-Switch/dp/B06XFXWLJP/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1515286479&sr=8-1&keywords=slide+switch+100+pc

Printer:

CR 10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed mine in 0.2 resolution, but you could probably do 0.3. Also for the infill I printed with 40% just because I was worried about the piece that goes in the hole might break off, but it was actually pretty stiff. So you might be able to go lower. I printed mine verticle, so z-axis should be the longest. I'm using the "Imagine That Titian/Atlas, Creality CR-10, Afinibot A31 Print Cooling". By RebelRousingProps. Go check out his print cooler for the CR -10 it works great. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2274499
I'm going to design a little box that hold the switch that screws on with the spool holder mount.

Notes:

Lamp Shade was printed with clear Polymaker Polysmooth.

How to Assemble the Lamp

Parts List:

3.7V 380 mah battery (Optional)
Link: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01N74S3LO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

1 Color changing led or any LED(s) you desire
Link: https://www.amazon.com/Multicolor-Flashing-Changing-Electronics-Components/dp/B01C19END2/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1515287390&sr=8-2&keywords=chanzon+color+changing

Charging / Power Board
Link: https://www.amazon.com/CHENBO-Lithium-Battery-Charging-Protection/dp/B06XCXPY86/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1515287501&sr=8-2&keywords=chenbo

Switch
Link:https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CQNQN4Q/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Hook-up Wire
Super Glue
Resistor
Sandpaper
Tape

Instructions:

  1. Begin by printing the base and shade and make sure they snap together properly using the tabs.

  2. Figure out what resistor to use to supply the proper amount of power to the LED(s) using http://led.linear1.org/1led.wiz.

  3. Using a fine grit sand paper dull up the outside of the LED(s) so that the light diffuses properly.

  4. Solder together the circuit by following the picture below.

  5. Super glue the switch and the power board into place and let dry.

  6. If a battery is used tape it in secure in the battery slot.

  7. Finally snap the base and shade together.

Just plug in a micro USB power supply and the lamp should be ready to use. I will upload a video later showing in greater detail on how to assemble the lamp circuit. If you have any questions let me know!

Component Layout

Designed to fit Xtreem Minidrone as in the pic.

The motors are 51.5 diam pitched with a 7mm top ring and 8mm bottom ring to clip into place.

As you an see in the pics it does fit other drones with similar motors and pitch.

This is a collection of inserts that are useful to insert into hydration bladders for the purpose of propping the sides apart so they dry faster and more thoroughly. I'm currently in training for an ultra marathon so I'm using bladders more often but even though I just use water I still worry about bad things growing in them so I like to swap between them and let them dry out between uses.

The inserts come in a variety of sayings including blank to save filament.

The size is such it should fit most bladders, at least it fits my Source, Platypus and Camelbak bladders. The hook part is designed to accommodate a variety of bladder makes so it may be too wide a gap for your specific bladder. In this case just heat it slightly with a lighter or candle and bend it, easy peasy.

Finishing

Solution and Image used in modeling Solving

author: TinkeringNerd

description.text: Remade this to be easliy printed without support/ overhangs.

This blowgun is a .40 cal blowgun at 36 Inches long. It is designed to be superglued together after printing. I have not printed this yet but am planning to when I get the chance. everything is plated for 1 print. The darts are an inch tall and designed to have something a millimeter wide like a paperclip go through the tip. Be safe & have fun

This print is designed to use as little outside peices as possible. You will, however, need some superglue. I prefer to wrap the blowgun in something like ductape and to add something relatively pointy to the darts. When it prints you'll notice that the bottoms of the poles seem to not have holes for the spikes, trust me they're there; there is a thin layer of filament covering the cavity. (Note: If the darts dont fit well into the blowgun sand down the rim at the base until it works well). Please leave feedback.

I made this for target practice but it's design is characteristic of that of real .40 cal blowguns.
BE CAREFUL and remember that the length gives this real power. do not shoot at anything you don't want damaged or injured.

description.text:
Improved case for XR2206 based Signal Generator kits, available many places (like here with an included awful acrylic case. This replaces the whole case except for the front panel, as that has hard to reproduce labeling on it.

ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS (these are pretty straigntforward):

  1. In the kit, there are some short screws and nuts, attach those to the board in the pre-drilled holes in the corners. These work as stand-offs. (shown in the second picture)
  2. Pop the board into the middle of this case. the bit of screw going past the nut should pop into the four holes down there.
  3. Put the acrylic plate with the labeling in the top part. It is a tight fit, but it should pop in with a little effort.
  4. Take some M3x20 bolts and M3 nuts. Put the nuts in the areas on the bottom, then put the bolts through the holes in the acrylic, through the case, and into the nuts, you can then tighten the bolts down.
  5. Finally, put on the included knobs for the potentiometers on the board.

The tolerances for this are a liiiittle tight, so be sure your printer's steps per mm are calibrated well. If anyone would like to make changes, the solidworks part file for this is included as well. (also, the reason the file is V6 is because that's how many tries it took for me to get this right)

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print with bottom of case against the bed. Be sure your printer's steps per mm are calibrated well.

May want to try using a higher infill or more outer perimeters, to avoid the small voids I have in my print. (I would have printed it again, but I wasted enough plastic on this already)

description.text: my first ever reprap design

This is a simple box for Ramps and Arduino.
It's cooled by an 80mm fan.
If you want fix the box to the left side of prusa I2, in this design, for now , there isn't any fix points.
Got tired of he noisy 30mm fan. Instead of creating a whole new jig, I simply created an adapter to fit between the original E3D shroud and a 40mm fan

Designed in Fusion 360

I made sure the scew tunnels for the inner 4 screws are 10mm as is the original fan. This way connecting the adapter to the original shroud is no different and can use the same screws.

Each printer behaves slightly different. the other screw holes are meant for m3 hex socket screws. The holes are printed at 3.2 mm and tightly fit when printed for me.

40mmx40mmx10mm fan: http://amzn.to/2F9C07f
hex socket m3 15mm: http://amzn.to/2COPruY
E3D All-metal v6 HotEnd Full Kit 1.75mm Universal: http://amzn.to/2qzXKG9

the blue shroud was borrowed from https://grabcad.com/library/e3d-v6-hotend-3

The actual sound you do hear in this video is not the hotend fan but the electronics cooling fan.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this in ABS for its flexibility.

description.text:
First, I have to give credit to Isemunda. His original design is what inspired this version I’m posting. Thank you!

This design is slightly wider than the original Husban X4; between rotors: original 65mm, mine 101.6 mm. This lends itself to a better hover and more controllable through turns. I added landing gear. These also serve as a place for a 500mAh battery; additionally it allows for a stable surface for resetting the gyros. I also added the A & B prop identifiers under the motor holding assemblies. Way easier to read than the original.

On top, I added taller gussets for greater strength and preventing the shearing off of the motor holding assembly. I also added areas for strapping down the board and battery. This has already held up better with crashes than the original body provided by the company.

I don’t mind the exposed wires, but if it bugs you….electrical tape will hold them down.

Good luck! Let me know how it goes for you!

remixed_from.title: MPSM Side vent (full) with gantry support

title: MPSM Side Panel - Bed Rewire , Gantry Support , Vent

description.text:
MPSM side panel 2 piece remix. I wanted to print flat using the MPSM (2 pieces required), add the bed rewire, gantry support (6mm rod with linear bearings), a small vent, and extra rigidity. I haven't been a fan of how 'wobbly' the existing side panels are - especially 2 pieces with gantry support. The main reason is that there isnt a bolt in the bottom-mid region, so breaking into pieces leaves an unsupported area in the middle. The bolted flange should make this behave like it is 1 piece, for all practical purposes.The webbing overlay feature also adds some extra rigidity (also adds some flair). Add a dab of super glue to hold the nuts on the right side of the flange to make it easy. Standard M3s are good. You'll need 2 linear bearings, a 6mm steel rod, and to 3D print the piece that zip-ties the bearings onto the cantilever arm that holds the extruder. I got the bearings and rod on Amazon.

Feature Summary;

  • Bed Rewire port
  • Air vent for circuit board
  • X gantry support
  • Bolted flange interface

You'll Need;

  • STL for extruder arm zip-tie mount ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1864625 )
  • 6mm rod
  • ~1-2 linear bearings (6mm)
  • 3x M3 bolts & nuts for flange

rod: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JR5G3VY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

bearings: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NQ36MBY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

M3 bolt kit: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072N2MLZH/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

description.text:
This meme has given me a lot of joy the last few days so I wanted to do my part to share it.

I reached out to the original modeler, tidiestflyer, on DeviantArt and he gave me permission to post the model here. Decided to go the extra mile and make it printable. Full cleaned up model is included, but won't print particularly well.
https://tidiestflyer.deviantart.com/art/The-Knuckles-meme-as-a-3d-model-704695335

Pin/hole shape is from emmett, 75% scale. Four pins needed. The built in ones in the legs aren't great due to the print orientation, so I may try to fix them later.
Had some flipped normals issues, but I think they're all fixed. Mirroring the good version is possible in a few slicers if you run into this issue.
Full height is just shy of 100mm tall.

Printed at Fargo 3D Printing using Fire Engine Red and Snow White APLA from 3D-Fuel.

2018/01/19 update: Added different leg files. Pins shouldn't break, but may wiggle a bit. I added a few drops of super glue to stabilize them.

title: Duet Wifi/Ethernet board adapter for FlashForge Creator Pro

description.text:
This "thing" is an adapter for mounting a Duet Wifi (or Duet Ethernet) inside a FlashForge Creator Pro (or any other machine that uses the same mounting holes) in place of the flashforge main board.

The adapter is designed to place the duet board so that the wifi antenna or ethernet jack is facing the back of the FFCP, and so the existing fan will blow over the area of the duet board where the stepper motors are located. There is a gap between the duet board and the back of the FFCP that should leave enough room for an ethernet plug to be plugged in (if you have a Duet Ethernet.) With this orientation, an Ethernet cable (and/or micro USB cable) can be routed through the hole in the back of the FFCP that was previously used for the USB jack.

READ ALL THE INFORMATION HERE CAREFULLY AND FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS.

I AM NOT IN ANY WAY RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY DAMAGE THAT MAY OCCUR AS A RESULT OF YOUR USING THIS MODEL. BE CAREFUL AND UNDERSTAND WHAT YOU'RE DOING! YOU ACCEPT ALL RESPONSIBILITY FOR ANYTHING GOOD OR BAD THAT MIGHT OCCUR. THIS INCLUDES BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO FIRES, EXPLOSIONS, THERMONUCLEAR WAR, TRUMP GETTING A SECOND TERM, ELECTRICAL SHORTS, DAMAGED EQUIPMENT, OR THE END OF LIFE ON EARTH AS WE CURRENTLY THINK WE KNOW IT.

Use ABS, PETG, or other heat resistant filament. (It may get warm enough to deform PLA.) Be sure to resize the model as needed for any filament shrinkage. No supports are needed, and a infill of 35% is fine. When slicing, pay attention to any preview and ensure the slicer isn't leaving gaps in the standoffs.

5x M3 flathead screws (for mounting the adapter in place of the mightyboard) Any length less than 10mm or so should be fine.

4x M3 screws (preferably with small heads) (for mounting the duet board to the adapter.) The length should be less than 8mm for these.

4x properly sized nylon, plastic (or other non-conductive) washers (for mounting the duet board - to prevent the 4 screws from having any electrical contact with the duet.)

4x M3 threaded heat set inserts. The model is designed for inserts with an overall length of 3.85mm and outside diameters of 5.6mm (top) and 5.12mm (bottom.) Here's an amazon link for the inserts I used: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B073W25CMX (I'm in no way associated with amazon, the seller, etc. That's a plain link with no kick backs.)

Once printed, use a soldering iron to insert M3 heat inserts into the 4 standoff holes. Let the inserts sink at least an extra millimeter into the plastic so the inserts can't make direct contact with the duet board.

Before screwing anything together, drop the screws you intend to use for mounting the adapter into the 5 hole, and place the duet board on the standoffs. Look in the gap and make sure that none of the screw heads can touch anything on the bottom of the duet board.

With the model prepared, you can remove the FF mightyboard clone from your machine, and screw this adapter in its place. It will only fit in one orientation with the standoffs facing out. DO NOT use the same cup head screws that the mightyboard used. Instead, I'd suggest using flathead screws (to prevent the screw tops from hitting the bottom of the duet board.) I'd even be paranoid and put some insulating tape over the screw heads.

Finally, the duet board can be attached using the final set of 4 M3 screws and washers. The washers go between the screw heads and the board (to prevent contact between the heads and the duet board.)

description.text:
These are offset head pads for the Sennheiser HD 580/600/650/6XX series headphones.

In recent years the top of my head has started getting sore during extended sessions where the headband rests on top of my skull. I replaced the foam head band insert with a new one from Sennheiser, but it didn't help that much because the same little contact patch was supporting the weight of the headset. I suppose a lot of this has to do with the fact that the curvature of the top of my head is a lot smaller radius than the curvature of Sennheiser's headband; I've got more of a Captain Picard-shaped head than most people.

I found myself wearing my headphones less and less, which bummed me out, so I came up with an idea to distribute the weight better for my head shape. I designed these two removable pad mounts to distribute the weight of the headphones across two areas on either side of the top of my head, and they have allowed me to go back to wearing them for much longer without getting a headache.

In my limited testing this part causes no damage to the stock headband, although as with anything on Thingiverse, you may use this design at your own risk and I refuse to accept any liability for damage or injury that may result.

Hardware list:

  • (4) #6-32 x 0.15" brass heat-set inserts for plastics (McMaster No. 93365A130)
  • (4) #6-32 x 0.5" socket cap machine screws
  • (4) #6x32 x 0.275" undersized washers (optional)
  • (2) pieces of foam, approximately 0.5" thick, 3.75" x 1.5", trim to fit pad mounts. I used chunks of an old closed cell foam Wal-Mart sleeping pad from the camping section, but any sufficiently firm/soft piece of foam will work, thick or thin as you like.
  • Glue to affix foam to pad mounts (I used a low temperature hot glue gun)
  • ~1/16" thick adhesive cork or one-sided foam tape for padding top of pad mount and bottom of top clamp where they squeeze touch headband. I bought the adhesive cork sheet I used at Hobby Lobby, its original purpose is for cupboard lining.

Special tools:

  • Soldering iron

Assembly:

  1. Trim the foam pads to fit the base of the pad mount, then glue them to the underside of the pad mount.
  2. Use the soldering iron to insert the brass heat-set inserts into the top holes on the pad mount. You may find instructional videos for this on YouTube.
  3. Cut your cork or foam tape and place it to just cover the area of the top of the pad mount that will touch the underside of the head band when installed.
  4. Cut your cork or foam tape and place it to just cover the area of the underside of the top clamp that will touch the top of the head band when installed.
  5. Place the socket cap machine screws through the holes in the top clamp with the washers (if used) and lightly install it around the outside edge of your headband as shown in the photos. The idea here is to use the minimum amount of torque on the screws necessary to keep the pad mounts in place. The cork or foam tape should provide some grip to keep it from sliding and some cushion to prevent marring of the finish on the head band, but you could still conceivably crush the plastic if you overtighten the screws.

Notes:

  • I used USCS spec fasteners (inches) but if you'd like to use metric fasteners the McMaster M3 brass heat set inserts have the same nominal diameter as the #6-32 variety I used, so you should be able to use M3 screws and inserts without any modifications to the STL/STEPs.

After printing take the adjustment nuts and heat them up enough to set in the plastic. It does't take much heat for PLA which is what I used. I gripped the heated adjustment nut with needle nose pliers as shown in the picture and pressed it into the printed knob.
Next, I took a bed leveling bolt and screwed it into the adjustment nut. I pulled it tight into the printed knob. I then spun it around the bolt and looked for wobble. I pressed on the knob where it was out of true to fine tune it.
I allowed it to cool before installing it back on the printer. The adjustment nut will melt it's grip pattern into the printed knob which will prevent any slippage later.

I tried other knobs people made and found the sizing was off. I designed these from scratch using Fusion360. I made the clearances slightly undersized so that the adjustment nuts could be set into the knob after being heated.

I finished geeking out my mini-delta!

This is my 3rd printer, my other current printer is an original Prusa i3 Mk2. I got the mini-delta due to low cost and I wanted to have a delta type printer.

Frustrated with the lack of a power button (hot plugging directly to the printer is bad bongos, too many pixies and it stops choochin), very loud printing and the PITA micro-SD. I decided to make some upgrades, all are warranty friendly.

Updates:

  1. Extended legs (make room for stuff and improve air flow)
  2. Snap in sidewalls for expansion space
  3. New bottom cover with finned fan mount, better air flow and lower sound level
  4. A/C converter pocket & wire managers
  5. Raspberry PI Zero mount (wireless printing)
  6. Full size SD card
  7. LED lighting w/switched power
  8. Cable management

I used my Prusa mk2 original (sorry too big to print these parts on the mini) and printed these parts using PETG. This update makes the fan related noise a bit less noisy. The motor movement noise is a bit reduced as well (not too much I sorry to say, I think the stepper drivers are just too noisy).

Parts List
⦁ Leg w/tie wrap mount - printed part
⦁ Leg w/cable manager - printed part
⦁ Wire retainer - printed part
⦁ Front wall - printed part
⦁ Left wall - printed part
⦁ A/C cover - printed part
⦁ Right side wall - printed part
⦁ Bottom fan cover - printed part
⦁ Raspberry Pi mounting bracket - printed part
⦁ SD card adapter retainer - printed part
⦁ Lower LED strip holder - printed part
⦁ Upper LED strip holder - printed part
⦁ M3x12 SEMs screws (legs)
⦁ M2.5 screw (RPI zero)
⦁ 6-32 x 1/2" screws (RPI zero / SD adapter)
⦁ LED strips (Ebay 200X10MM 10W DC12-24V COB LED Strip)
⦁ Raspberry Pi Zero W
⦁ D/C power receptacle (from my parts bin)
⦁ C8 A/C power receptacle (Amazon ASIN B01IS89C8G)
⦁ Toggle SPST switch (Amazon UPC 602914875493)
⦁ 9v wall wart (from my parts bin)
⦁ TF Micro SD to SD adapter (Amazon ASIN B06XY5QB2Z)

comments.text:
The tolerance on the screw is very low (or none), which makes it very hard to screw together. Therefore I printed the screw scaled to 98%, which works fine (it is ok for the PTFE tube and the filament hole).
I would also recommend printing with lower layer height (0.15 or even 0.1 works fine with good PETG), otherwise screw-thread is not really print correctly.

title: Wall Mount for Nintendo Switch Dock

description.text:
This is a simple two part design. that keeps the USB Ports open and allow the cords to run out the side of the mount.

This is modeled for Type K 3/4" wood screws.
Screw holes are counter sunk for 10mm flat head screws.

Questions, comments, suggestions? Feel free to reach out to me!
I printed at .1 layer height and 20% grid infill. It's a bit over Zealous, you could definitely produce it at lower resolutions/infill.

Mount Installation:

  1. Draw a line where you would like the top or bottom of your Switch to sit.
  2. Place the Mount Pieces to both sides of the Dock and place it on the line.
  3. trace the left and right edges of the mount.
  4. Remove the mount from the dock and realign in the mounting area.
  5. Mark the screw whole on the mounting area.
  6. Follow Steps needed for drilling and screwing into the substrate in the mounting area.

Dock Install:

  1. Mount both side of the mount before placing the dock.
  2. Thread your cables through the right bracket of the mount, attach them to the dock. (image 3)
  3. Rotate the left Mount slightly to get the Dock sitting into the right bracket. (image 4) This is generally cause the left bracket to come into place but there's a bit of play so you may need to rotate the left bracket into place all the way. (image 5)

Note: It's a tight fit but you will get it in there!

remixed_from.author: Tomodachi1
remixed_from.title: Rotary tool Fan - Dremel and others

description.text:
This is a fan that friction fits onto the collect of a Dremel/Craftsmen 395 rotary tool. It blows air over the bit to clear the dust from the cutting area so you can see better.

I remixed the original design as I didn't like the exposed fan blades, so I added a shroud around them. I was also interested in coming up with an optimal blade design to move the most air. I designed and tested 23 different ideas then measured and charted their output. The top 3 are available for download.

There are 3 different fan styles, two that are 25mm in diameter, one that is 20mm. I added the smaller one as I found the larger fans sometimes obscured the bit too much doing fine work. There's also a version without keying for rotary tools that don't have any.

Designed for 10.6mm diameter collet. If yours is larger/smaller, just scale the part up down. It requires a friction fit to stay attached.

description.text:
REMIX SHOUT OUT
Tinkerman's "Filament Dryer / Dehydrator" thing provided inspiration for this project, and let me know what already existing things I could re-purpose and use as part of this project.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1618037

I needed a way to restore old filament that was no longer printing well. Research suggested that moisture in the filament may be the cause, and that the filament needed to be dehydrated. I found the "PrintDry Filament Drying System" which is specifically designed for this purpose, and noticed that it looked very similar to a food dehydrator I saw at a local store, with the same temperature ranges available on its control dial. So being a maker, I chose to modify a food dehydrator to dry my filament; this turned out to be pretty easy. Here's what I did:

1] I used the base of a "Salton VitaPro Food Dehydrator" (the source of warm air feeding the dehydration process) which I found for $40. I set aside the trays and lid, keeping them intact and not used for this project.
• https://www.walmart.ca/en/ip/salton-vitapro-food-dehydrator/6000187742641

2] I designed and printed an adaptor piece, to hold my filament spool on the food dehydrator's warm air vent, instead of using one of the dehydrator's food trays.
• Remix Note: I did not use Tinkerman's "Spool Axes", but I did make use of the step element of his design when I made this one.

3] For a cover with a comparable air volume, I found a food serving tray with a dome cover at my local thrift store. It was only a slightly smaller diameter than the dehumidifier, and I got it for only $3. It looks very similar to this one:
• https://www.amazon.ca/Estilo-EST0314-Multifunctional-Serving-Stand/dp/B016V65CUE/ref=sr_1_2

4] I drilled several holes in the top of the domed cover, to approximately match the volume of the air gaps in the food dehydrator's original lid, allowing air flow for the dehydration process.

5] to prevent cover vibration rattle when operating, I used a piece of soft PVC tubing (similar to aquarium air hose), in which I cut a lengthwise slit, then slid it onto the bottom edge of the cover.
• https://www.princessauto.com/en/detail/1-8-in-clear-pvc-tubing-nsf/A-p8576308e

Sketchup 2017 source files for the filament spool mounting adaptor are included in the thing files.

chickens whirligig revisited.

In the year since I first posted my Chickens whirligig, some problems have come up. This is my attempt to fix them.

The main problem has been that it takes quite a bit of force to get the whirligig spinning. My solution is a set of geared pulleys and a 3-D printed ninjaflex geared belt. The pulleys offer a 2 to 1 ratio, so for each revolution of the propeller, the chicken cams only go through half of a revolution. This has the effect of making it easier to drive the mechanism, slowing down the action and making it smoother.

One pulley is mounted to a new bearing block under the front bottom base, while the other is mounted to the original drive shaft. I designed a new bottom front base that incorporates the new bearing block, and also included a design that is just the bearing block for anyone who (like me) just wants to retrofit an existing whirligig. It can just be glued to the front of the existing base.

Some other changes I made include moving the pivot point on the hen so she looks more natural and a redesigned and hopefully better worm cam.

In an effort to further make the action smoother, I inserted lengths of teflon bowden tube for 1.75mm filament into each of the holes that have chicken movement wires running through them. The tubing has an o/d of 4mm and just fits nicely in the existing holes. This step is not necessary, but I had the tubing, it was cheap, and it fit, so why not?

One more thing, after most of a year outside, the ABS plastic I used for this print has gotten brittle. For most of the whirligig, it doesn't matter much, but none of the chicken legs held up very well. The ones that weren't already broken when I started broke while I was working on it. I have replaced the ABS plastic with TPU for the legs. I think this will work out much better. I haven't tried PLA, but doubt it would do any better than ABS.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OpM4_1eJkdw

Parts List

You will need the following hardware:

1 1/4 - 20 threaded rod for the main axle. Cut to length
1 1/4 - 20 threaded rod for the lower axle
17 1/4 - 20 nuts
3 1/4 - 20 nyloc nuts
2 6-32 X 3/4" machine screws and nuts
4 4-40 X 3/4" machine screws and nuts
1 4-40 X 1" machine screw
2 feet of stiff, fine wire. I used 1/32" (about .8mm) diameter wire I had.
1 5/16 threaded rod
2 5/16 nyloc nuts
2 608zz skateboard bearings
4 r4-zz skateboard bearings

Feel free to substitute the closest metric equivalent.

When attaching the wires, keep them loose enough to ride freely around the cam. To keep drag at a minimum, make sure the wire is as straight as possible where it goes through the holes in the base. I wound up testing and adjusting everything with just the wires (no chickens) until everything worked without binding up anywhere. Then I added the chickens.

For the worm, I drilled the hole out big enough so that I could thread the 4-40 machine screw into it. The fit was good enough that I didn't have to glue it. The wire that rides on either side of the worm cam is wrapped around the machine screw, then trapped between two nuts. I had better luck printing the worm and getting it to fit by using TPU instead of a harder plastic.

description.text:
This Thing contains .stl files to print several 28mm scale upright Arcade Game Cabinets. They're intended to add interesting scatter terrain to 28mm scale Science Fiction or Modern war games. In the files you'll find three upright Arcade Cabinets, and two Control files which will let you print a total of six different cabinet + control combinations.

For more designs and 28mm war gaming terrain check out my blog: http://www.tabletop-terrain.com

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The Arcade Cabinets should load into your slicer so they are laying on their backs, with the screen and other details face up (in the Z axis). If not please rotate before printing. There's a generic cabinet design, and two designs inspired by classic 1980's Arcade games.

The Controls are small separate prints that are designed to be glued to the printed cabinets. One is a classic two player joystick setup, and the other is a one player trackball design.

As my printer isn't capable of particularly smooth first layers, I like to cover the back of each finished cabinet with some 0.1mm Plastruct plastic card. This gives the cabinet some simple extra detailing, and hides any print bed defects.

Additionally, while painting the finished pieces, consider painting their bases as well. That way they can be flipped on their sides for lower horizontal cover for your war game.

Gloss varnish also works nicely if applied to the screens once normal painting and varnishing is complete.

title: Rektify - Fully Automatic Foam Dart Blaster

description.text:
Rektify is a sophomorically named full-auto foam dart blaster. It is compatible with 130 to 180 sized DC brushed motors (possibly only 130 as a pusher though it may fit without a voltmeter), and accepts most magazines compatible with Hasbro Nerf blasters (compatibility with Buzz Bee mags is not guaranteed). Additional design features include a horizontal flywheel cage, 14mm bore, flat-top with a full-length of picatinny rail, and top-loadability. It accepts full sized or submini microswitches for its flywheel and pusher switches, but only submini sized ones for its cycle control switch.

Optional additions include: Voltmeter mount, kill switch mount, an internal battery tray (89x52x20mm), a stock mount that doubles as a tray door, and an entire printable stock that includes a significantly larger battery tray (125x50x30mm). The scotch yoke pusher can either be one with a dwell or a simple straight slotted yoke (former may result in more reliable cycle control, latter is easier on the gearbox). Cage options now include 41.5mm, 43mm spacing, Eclipse, with optional dart guides, and 14 and 16mm bores for non-Eclipse cages (former for better precision, latter for more reliability especially with top-loading).

Required for Assembly:

  • Three 130-180 sized motors. 180 sized motors may not fit as a pusher.
  • 33 to 37mm OD flywheels (all superstock flywheels as of now)
  • Arduino TT-gearbox
  • 14-18 AWG hobby wire
  • Connector of your choice and heat shrink (or alternatives, but heat shrink is optimal)
  • Full-sized and/or submini microswitches. Cycle control switch cannot be full-sized.
  • Screwdriver compatible with M3 screws
  • Allen key compatible with M3 screws
  • M3 nuts
    M3 Screws:
  • 5mm length, 10mm length, 14mm length, and 25mm length (Not all must be exact)
    (Some MUST be hex or torx head for joining the magwell, preferably all)
  • M3 washers in areas where the aforementioned screws are too long.
    M2 Screws:
  • 4-5mm length, 10mm length.
  • A 30mm (in length) extension spring
  • An adhesive of some sort (superglue will suffice) for the CC Follower

Some extra connectors for modular flywheel cages and pusher boxes are highly recommended, and also recommended are bullet connectors to join the cycle control switch to the trigger switches (though it is possible without them, it's tricky).

The CC0 license is there for a reason. Do whatever you want with this thing, edit it however you want, sell it even, and don't even ask me. I don't care. It's all yours.

Update Notes:

V1.1: Adjusted magwell and mag release to fix alignment issues that would cause inconsistent feeding.
V1.2: Redesigned stock mounting screws to ALL be able to fit M3 nuts for four durable threads and more rigidity (rather than only two and some wobble). Also modified internal battery tray to allow XT60s to slide out.
V1.3: V1.2's M3 nut friction fit was too tight by half a millimeter, fixed those tolerances.
V1.4: Added 41.5mm flywheel cage, removed 43mm dart guide from F3D file to troubleshoot. STL for it remains, but no dart guide for the 41.5mm cage yet.
V1.5: Modified cage opening fillet to a chamfer to improve feeding reliability.
V1.6: Added a more refined dart guide design, also to the 41.5mm cage.
V1.7: Removed F3D file from zip downloadable - file size is now down two-thirds and it plays nice with Thingiverse not making buggy downloads. Relocated being able to edit the file to a public link instead.
V1.8: Revised designs for the 'Upper' to be less janky in geometry (still not perfect) and be printable upside down - possibly without supports.
V1.9: Big update here. The Eclipse cage is out. Also cosmetic and structural refinements, such as having the carry handle attach to the top of the magwell, minimizing the motor and flywheel covers, and do note that the old magwell will no longer be compatible with the updates. Also slightly raised the limit bar for the mag release to allow a brim for the magwell to adhere it both inside and out.
V1.95: Yes, I'm trying really hard here to avoid reading 2.0 (there's a bigger update planned which I still have to test). The minimized motor cover's tolerances were too close for comfort (talking fitting 132s without shell cutting close), so it's been given more breathing room. Bulkier, but better than smashed terminals.
V2.0: Another decent sized update here, they include: 16mm bore cages, recommended for reliability with top-loading, a grip completely redesigned to be clamshell with improved ergonomics, redesigned triggers to have less wobble, ambidextrous sling mount points, and other minor optimizations.
V2.1: Optimized grip ergonomics, redesigned trigger and trigger guard to both be less disproportionately large and lower in position.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15-0.3

Infill:

10-30%

Notes:

Supports required for flywheel cage and brims are highly recommended for larger parts.

Whole blaster will consume about 800-900 grams of filament, 600-700 grams excluding the printable stock.

PUBLIC LINK: http://a360.co/2mVft6Y

comments.text: Magwell's side cut-out was directly inspired by the FDL, though how the actual magwell functions is closer to a Caliburn and it's one piece mag release. The monolithic horizontal FWC has been used quite a bit at this point so I don't think you can really call that an example anymore. Otherwise, the differences pile up - this is meant to have conventional ergonomics, be top-loadable, and have a full flat-top of picatinny, none of which really apply to the FDL. Sure, the FDL-2 is a much more refined design, I don't believe any of those were design goals upon its conception.

You will need:

-Insert PTFE Tube in opening (push hard).
-Insert filament in tube and then put the screws in (the filament prevents the tube from sqeezing on itself).

Printed In PLA 0.4, and layer 0.2

Adapt these two designs to work together.

Proteus solder station has a nice design, but the ball fitting system is weak. So I used the other stronger design and added an adaptation to work together.

Also, use four RJ45 cables for greater stability in the balls and original joints, plus power carrying or cable testing. These cables go to a protoboard behind the cooler.

Realice una adaptacion para que estos dos diseños trabajen juntos.

Proteus solder station tiene un diseño lindo, pero el sistema de ajustes de bolas es debil. Asi que use el otro diseño mas fuerte y agrege una adaptacion para que trabajen juntos.

Tambien use cuatro cables de RJ45 para que tenga mayor estabilidad en las bolas y juntas originales, ademas de poder llevar energia o hacer pruebas con cables. Estos cables van a un protoboard detras del cooler.

description.text:
I designed these flashing model train railroad flashing signals as part of a larger project (which I'll eventually post) for my father's model railroad. They are designed to be "O" scale or gauge (roughly 48:1).

These are fairly small, about 5" in height, and as they are hollow, can be a bit fragile, so handle with care post-printing. The post includes a base which prints in place and allows movement to screw these to a model railroad table). Connections requiring drilling holes through the table as all wires exit the bottom of the posts.

Video of finished working models (in a gift box)... is posted.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-zz95TgvddU&feature=youtu.be

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

1) Railroad Crossing Sign

  • I print without supports
  • I print the first ~5 layers in white, pause the printer and switch to black filament... resume printing for the text... it takes some practice, but works great.
  • I don't paint these.

2) Post

  • I print without supports (I want the interior hollow).
  • I print in gray, but as it gets painted, could be any color

3) Arms

  • I print with supports to base, as shown (only on the cup which is elevated... the interior of the arm doesn't need supports (I want the interior hollow).
  • I print in gray, but as it gets painted, could be any color

4) Flashers

  • I print with supports to base, as shown (requires cleanup to ensure proper fitting of LED and onto arm.
  • I print in black so I don't have to paint later.

Wiring and Painting

Process:

1) Preparing and soldering the LEDs

  • I started by identifying the longer leg of the LED (the anode) which is for positive input and cut each leg short (5-7mm), leaving the anode a little longer so I could identify it, then bent these wires at a 90 degree angle (has to fit through the signal arm). I slipped on some shrink wrap and then wire wrapped the red and black wires onto the LED, soldering them and then sliding the shrink wrap back over the joints and applied heat to prevent a short.

2) Wiring the LEDs

  • I fed a black/red pair of wires with LED through the signal arm and fitted the black flasher housing over each LED to ensure fit before feeding this pair through the post and down to the bottom.

3) Test the signal

  • Connect signal circuit (see link), or apply 5V with a current limiting resistor to test without it).

4) Epoxy

5) Paint

  • Your choice on order... I found it easier to paint (using multiple acrylic based metallic silvers and grays) before assembling and epoxying.

Electronics:

I used 3mm LEDs for the flashers such as these)

  • https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/500Pcs-lot-3MM-LED-Diode-Kit-Mixed-Color-Red-Green-Yellow-Blue-White/221555_32568906277.html?spm=2114.12010615.0.0.1127a62dYTaGo2

I used wire wrapping wire (I believe AWG30) and a wire wrapping tool on each LED

  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wire_wrap

I used this 5V circuit to flash the LEDs (very inexpensive) and I control it with an Arduino UNO's single output... turning an output "HIgh", sending 5V to the input of this circuit (which only pulls 6-9ma)

  • https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/3pcs-DIY-Kit-Simple-Flash-LED-Light-Circuit-Simple-flashing-Leds-Circuit-Board-Kits-5MM-LED/1829717_32810838231.html?spm=2114.12010615.0.0.3f052c801eUqXc

title: X-axis Right Side Endstop Holder for Prusa i3 (Remix)

description.text:
This is a remix of this endstop holder which was in turn remixed from yet another endstop holder. I remodeled it so that it works on the right side of the printer (x-max) since the original only works on the left side (x-min). The most recent build guide for the Folgertech 2020 i3 (as of January 2018) says that the endstop should be mounted on the right side. I have also lengthened one of the cutouts that wasn't long enough. I'm not sure if this works with other Prusa i3 variants, the 8mm rods on my machine are about 45mm apart measured from the center of one rod to the center of the other. Please comment if you were able to use this on a different printer.

Currently known compatible printers:
-Folgertech 2020 i3
-Folgertech i3 (acrylic frame)

title: Duet Wifi housing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really liked the original by pcsentinel but decided to make a few modifications to fit my needs.

Overall the design was brilliant so my modifications included:

  • adding cable tie slots at the entrances and in a few other places to hold the cables
  • adding a case front that allows the USB connector to be used and the SD card to be accessed
  • slightly resizing the box
  • adding lugs to locate the small box against the larger one
  • changing the lid hold down screw arrangement to suit the excellent servo screws from Modelfixings
  • removing the label inserts on the lid to give more flexibility about label size and location

I retained the excellent light pipe idea - sheer brilliance!

title: Hubsan x4 H107C Tie Fighter Conversion

description.text:
I really liked the idea of turning a quadcopter into a tie fighter, but didn't want to gut my perfectly fine Hubsan x4 H107C to do so. Instead, I took Mysabre73's tie fighter wing and modified it. I then designed connectors to attach the wings to the hubsan quad. The linkage is a simple connector that is stable enough to fly and land, but can separate on a rough landing or crash limiting breakage. I designed it to fit the 8.5mm motors of the h107c. I'll try to post a video to show the hubsan tie fighter in flight.....video: https://youtu.be/kVQgXMwr6eo

Print 4x of Tie Fighter Hubsan connector v2.stl
Print 2x of Tie Fighter Hubsan panel.stl

I printed with PETG for added durability and flexibility, also I had the colors I needed. I'm guessing PLA or ABS would be fine. I printed at 100% infill because the parts are small and thin and with 2-3 walls it was practically solid anyway, might as well go all the way. At .2mm layer height I printed first two layers for the panel/wing in black and the remaining layers in grey.

A laight sanding may be necessary for the connectors and motor mounts to remove small burs or abnormalities.

If desired, you could glue the pieces together, but I didn't see a need and have flown many times without issue. Just be gentle on the landings.
I designed this in TinkerCAD.

print_settings.Notes:: Printing is easy.

description.text:
If you are tired of fiddling with your keyboard to adjust the volume on your computer while sitting back and watching movies, and if your speakers and the volume knob are located out of the way, try this dedicated USB volume knob.

This is a USB volume knob device made to house a rotary encoder and an Arduino-compatible Adafruit Trinket.

The setup is described in detail on Adafruit's excellent website: https://learn.adafruit.com/trinket-usb-volume-knob/overview

Common Issues With Trinket

If you've never worked with Adafruit's Trinket board, read the setup instructions carefully: https://learn.adafruit.com/introducing-trinket/setting-up-with-arduino-ide

We had to install this driver first: https://learn.adafruit.com/introducing-trinket/windows-setup

You also need to hit the reset button on the Trinket before hitting the upload button on the Arduino IDE to upload the sketch. Experiment with the timing. For ours, we had to hit reset and immediately hit upload after we heard the USB disconnect chime on our desktop.

We permanently soldered the wires from the encoder to the Trinket. BE CAREFUL when wiring your project. Switched wires can burn out your Trinket!!!

Concrete Infill

You can make this as is, or you can mix 3 parts sand, 1 part cement and add a concrete infill as pictured to give it a nice weighted feel. The knob comes with a cover, so you can add concrete in the knob as well, then friction weld or glue the cover in place.

Leave the concrete to dry overnight. Test fit the knob cover to make sure you didn't place too much concrete in. If there is excess concrete, the day after you can still scratch out the excess material and fit the cover.

Other popular methods of providing infills include hot wax and metal pellets. We didn't do this because 3D printing uses thermoplastic and heat could warp the parts. Experiment at your own risk.

Securing the Knob

To secure the knob onto the rotary encoder, use some hot glue. We used an earlier knob version with a semi-circle interface that did not fit our encoder. We drilled it out, but the knob now is slightly lopsided. The knob included in the STL files is a full circle so glue will be required to secure it to the rotary encoder. Double check alignment to avoid leaving it lopsided.

Securing the Rotary Encoder

Since we don't know what encoder you have, we made the encoder bracket a separate part that can be redesigned in SketchUp to fit whichever one you have on hand. It is essential that the encoder sits in the channel centered. We friction welded the bracket in place and can slide the encoder in and out of the channel. We used a dab of hot glue to secure it in place after prototyping was done.

Web Shooters from The Amazing Spiderman film.

title: CR-10 upgrade Dual Z from single stepper

description.text:
This is my attempt at dual-Z upgrade for CR-10 using a single stepper motor.

It uses a 600mm lead screw kit such as this one:

https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/3D-Printer-T8-Trapezoidal-Lead-Screw-Rod-W-Nut-Coupling-Shaft-Bearing-Mount-Set/152604546903?hash=item2387f09757:m:mBqqygoYqpae9LmSj9iyFCQ

making use of the pillow block bearings and lead screw nut that are provided in the kit.

Also requires:
2x 20 tooth 8mm hole GT2 drive pullet
1x 20 tooth 8mm hold GT2 smooth idler
1x 760mm GT2 belt

2x M5x40mm bolts (to lengthen right hand side X carrier bolts to take new bracket.
4x M5 nylon lock nuts
4x M5x12mm (hex head) to take the pillow block bearings
4x M5x8mm (pan head) to lock bearing brackets into the CR-10 frame
4x M5 hammer head/t-slow nuts

for the tensioner listed below:
M5 x 50mm bolt (hex head)
M5 x 30mm bolt
2x M5 nuts

The stock lead screw is moved to the right hand side. The 600mm lead screw replaces the stock screw on the left hand side connected to the stepper motor.

print_settings.Notes:: Cap - 100% infill, no supports

description.text:
Needed a filament guide above my extruder to hold the filament off some cable ties that it occasionally rubbed against. But I also needed it to be out of the way to load the filament easier. I designed this to meet both requirements.

Designed for the extruder assembly on an Anet A8, but there's no reason it couldn't be used anywhere on any printer with a conveniently positioned screw. Slot is for 1.75mm filament.

I've also added a hinge pin and cap, however these are very small (M3) so if they don't work for you, just stick an M3 screw through it. The hole is pretty tight for this, which keeps the hinge more rigid.

Happy Printing.

Notes:

Guide and Mount - With supports

Pin - Thread pointing up, 100% infill with Brim, no supports

Cap - 100% infill, no supports
just an atom

title: Tarot t-2D gimbal GoPro lens protector holder

description.text:
To replace the aluminium lens holder and allows the use of the lens protectors from gopro. Having tested the fit, this works well. The larger model would require the lens protector to be glued into the tarot holder using silicone as this is removable. I will post a working picture once I have sorted my skipping issue! Just seen this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:255967 from Clough42, nice design for the same thing. I did try and find any on here before, but maybe that was before Feb 22nd! Anyways his design is smaller and lighter, but i feel this design, being bigger, allows you to fix the lens protector too, as i know they are only
a push fit, and in the event of a crash, the lens protector could fall off?... thats my opinion, but check it out too! link above.

comments.text: Thanks a lot for this plan. I made it as my first project. I have a question concerning the screw holes, which are too big. What do you recommend using to fill the holes so that the screws can create their threads? I found a variety of solutions on the Web, but they seem to be for bigger projects and/or permanent attachements. I was imagining some sort of adhesive or resin that would dry around the screw... Thanks
comments.author: fredojean

comments.text:
I will reupload a smaller design.
If you want to, you can fill with molten plastic from your plastic nozzle by placing the hole by the extruder nozzle and extrude into it. Then drill out for M2 bolt.
Or you can use a resin, fast setting. One thing im playing with is some thermal inserts which will eventually be a beeter option. If you want more info on these see: http://www.roboteernat.co.uk/2014/03/thermal-inserts-for-3d-printed-parts/http://www.roboteernat.co.uk/2...
Otherwise a good hard plastic glue will work, just need to tap out the thread or glue it in for permenant fitting (not ideal!)
Some people use rubber bands to fit it on, but i dont like this as it may result in loss of camera!
Hope that helps!

yet another CNC design all 3d printed parts except:
  • frame ( 40mm aluminium profiles )
  • motors ( standard NEMA17 steppers )
  • rails + linear bearings ( 10mm smooth rods + LM10UU )
  • rods + bearings ( M8 standard threaded rods + 608ZZ )
    • designed in OpenSCAD

There are 4 OpenSCAD files: cnc_inc.scad contains all size definitions and shared modules
cnc_x.scad, cnc_y.scad and cnc_z.scad contain the actual design for each axis To create the STL files: First check the measurements in cnc_inc.scad . These probably need adjusting to match print settings.
Then load cnc_x, cnc_y or cnc_z.scad and set the print variable ( 0 - preview the whole thing, 1..n - cycles through each part for export )
These are supports for blocking the glass on the hotbed of the Anet A8. The supports can also be used on other printers, also the support without hole.

title: YO-YO_Customized
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I came across a fusion 360 tutorial from "instructables" that provides a good tutorial on how to use fusion 360 basic shapes and functions to create a Yo-Yo.

Because I'm new to fusion 360 and teaching myself I decided to go through the stepped processes, but I did change it up a bit and put my little buddies embossed image on the Yo- Yo instead of the "fusion logo" as the originator Vladimira did. I also resized the Yo-Yo to approximately 58mm in diameter (closer to a standard size), as the original was too large.

I then created a recess pocket for the end caps. Making them so that one could swap them out with different choices for the end caps. Simply customize your own logo, image, design, stamp, text or blank onto the end caps for personalization of the Yo-Yo.

(https://www.instructables.com/id/Use-Fusion-360-to-Make-a-YO-YO/)
by Vladimira Novotna,

title: Trinus Kodama Wobble Fix Beta (and prevent cracked glass.)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a stretch this will help anyone but I designed this the other day for someone. I don't think they're using it in objection to hex nuts being used for the z axis. I noticed that my hex nuts move as freely as my flangers so I decided to upload this.

You'll need a t8 hex nut. Some patience.

I have no instructions for this one as I don't own the printer. If anyone wants to make any modifications and do a tutorial that would be grand. I'm uploading this in hopes someone may benefit but I see little outcomes in this.

There's talk that floating z axis does little to help you. I've noticed an extreme difference but for the Trinus I'm not sure you'll see anything. Nonetheless, if you're up for a challenge - this would definitely prevent glass bed cracking at the very least.

Hopefully someone has a use but for the time being it's just a vapor-ware model in the sense that I'll never use it.

title: AH-KU MkII (Scout/Melee Mech)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hello again,

This time it took longer because I resorted to rough sketches and imagination in terms of the design. Used various bits and bobs from around the web for inspiration, but it's not a blatant copy of any particular design. It's actually quite challenging to come up with a mech design, but eventually I came up with something I like and, hopefully, you'll too.

I called it AH-KU MKII (Autonomous Hunter-Killer Unit, Mark 2) - dubbed "Cheetah" - as speed, camouflage and agility are what brings it to close quarters combat at which it excels. Being caught out in the open though renders it almost helpless.

Blender all the way, as usual.
If anyone's interested, the presentation screen was made using Substance Painter.

title: Solid Z-Axis Spring Holder for Lulzbot TAZ

description.text: This is a modified part for the Lulzbot TAZ 2.0 3D printer. It should also work fine for the TAZ 3.0 3D printer since this part was unchanged between the two models. The part is the Z-Axis holder. The original design had a curvey shape that gave it some flex in the Z-Axis. I found this to create inaccuracies in the Z-Axis and it also broke at one point so wanted something more solid. This part is dimensionally identical so you can swap it directly, but is a solid block of plastic. Having made this "upgrade" the Z-Axis is more rigid. I prefer this, although I'm unsure whether it significantly improves the print quality. I feel like the print quality is better with these new Z-Axis holders. This work was derived from LulzBot's original TAZ 2.0 designs. https://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/2.0/

• Print two of the .stl file, you can use either ABS or PLA. I printed with a 0.3mm layer height.

  • Remove support.

  • Turn the printer on and home all axes.

  • Move the X-axis most of the way to the right. The nozzle should be just about resting on the bed.

  • Unscrew the old Z-Axis holders and rest the nozzle on the bed and the Z-Axis stop on the stop button.

  • In the TAZ control panel, go to Prepare > Move Axis > Move 1mm > Z-Axis and move all the way to 250mm. You will have to hold the two Z-Axis holders while the unscrew all the way to the top.

  • Unscrew the last part manually.

  • Remove all of the metal parts from the original Z-Axis holders. You'll probably need to destroy them in the process.

  • Fit the metal grub nuts into the new Z-Axis holders by pushing them in with a soldering iron. They will conduct the heat from the soldering iron and melt the plastic around them. When the plastic dries, they will be perfectly fitted.

  • Put the metal nuts into the new Z-Axis holders.

  • Put the springs into the new Z-Axis holders. This can be quite tricky, you need to compress it all the way to get it in.

  • Screw the new Z-Axis holders all the way back down to their rightful positions and fix them into place. This can be done manually or by using the control panel. A second pair of hands would be useful here.

description.text:
Yes, I know :
Why another one ?
Actually, I started with this model: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1506041.
And I decided to improve it a bit:

  • First I added a thread on each bearing poll, to fix the bearing with a nut.
  • Finally, I used two threaded stem to maintain the slides. The threads are left handed on one end, and right handed on the other. A semi-square section allows turning a stem easily, to modify the distance between the slides. Thus, you can quickly and safely adjust the spool holder to your needs.

This is the followup of my ABHA Rodin Coil Frame (Phi proportions, 36x36 pattern) design, which can be found at => https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2710529.
This design consists of 2 ABHA Rodin coils nested, according to Tom Barnett's research.
This has a 400mm outside diameter 3rd order Rodin coil, with 36x36 pattern, which inside it has a 247mm outside diameter Rodin Coil with a 36x9 pattern, Phi proportioned.
How to route the wire on the 400mm 3rd order coil refer to the above design link. You will find all the maths and related video links there too. The main research into this design configuration can be seen here on Tom Barnett's video link, starting from the actual section that is relevant, https://youtu.be/kxuU8jYkA1k?t=304.
Wire routing on the large one is identical to the 3rd order design with the link above. Of course, you need to build the 1st order, smaller coil first. The wire routing is exactly the same as on the big one, every second groove on the adjacent former/rib, see the colour marked former ending on the relevant photo. On the small 1st order coil the wire routing passes through the centre of the coil 4 times while only goes around once, pattern 36x9. On the large outside 3rd order coil passes through the centre once and goes around once, see images.
Once the inside coil building is completed place in the centre of the large one and use the clips to hold them in place. 3-4 clips will be sufficient to hold the assemble together. See close up image of the clip and how to put it on, last image of the assembly. As you route the wires around it, it will be even more securely locked into position.
All the printer settings and notes regarding printing is identical to the project that has the link above.
If you decide to build this configuration in a smaller scale, I would suggest not to reduce it below 75% of this designs original size.
All parts will fit a 200mm x 200mm print bed.

Research Suggestions

As we know, the Rodin coil can magnetically couple with devices outside of its magnetic vortex. The perfect experiment for this is to get a magnet ball in the centre of the coil, in a container, and the magnet ball will start to spin really fast. While the coil is still on, remove the magnet with its container from the centre of the coil and you will find that the magnet will still spin 1-2m, 3-7ft, away and more and does not slow down or stops. The spin will not stop up to a certain distance only, of course. I think there are some videos on YouTube demonstrating this effect.
Using this information we should experiment how the external coil interacts with the internal one when the outside, 3rd order, is driven and vica versa. There are many configurations that can be experimented with based on how the wiring is done on the coils, using different frequencies and power.
Expecting that this Phi proportion configuration suggested by Tom Barnett will produce some interesting results with the nested setup.
To my knowledge, there wasn't any experiment conducted with this configuration. Please share your results if you decide to give it a go.

NOTE: I make no claim or warranty about safety or stability of these under the bearing of any load. You do so at your own risk.

I had Bought this bed from Ikea: http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/30360487/

Turns out the mattresses they displayed with it were about an inch too tall for the beds to properly stack, so I made these risers to fit between the beds to accommodate the added mattress heights. I printed them with 65% infill because I was paranoid about the sturdiness and support in case someone accidentally sat or jumped onto the stacked beds while I had the risers in there.

title: Acoustic Tractor Beam - Enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a handheld Acoustic Tractor Beam which can levitate small light objects like Styrofoam balls. It is based on the design made by Asier Marzo, to which I made a 3D-printable enclosure and change some of the electrical components, all this to make it a bit more integrated and usable friendly. The material and components for the original project and instructions on how to build it can be found at: http://www.instructables.com/id/Acoustic-Tractor-Beam/

The CAD file for Rhino (.3dm) is also provided so that you can modify the enclosure as you like.

Feel free to post you prints!

Printer:

Geeetech G2s Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

~0.2mm

Infill:

Regular

Finishing touches

Holes for cables and such are not made in the design, since this was a one-of pioneer build, and so also mounting hole to fix the battery holder. Furthermore, the bottom of the bowl from the original project needs to be removed to make room for the driver. This part of the bowl is not of concern because no transducers are needed there anyhow. Chamfering the top edge of the bowl is also a good idea.

Components

The difference in material as appose to the original design are as follow. I used a 3,7V Li-ion battery, of type 18650, with holder and a USB-changing/step-up circuit to supply the l Arduino Mini Pro and "L298N" Dual Motor Driver with 5VDC. The main power switch is a regular single pole type and it is connected after the battery's charge/step-up circuit. After that I use an other step-up circuit to drive the transducers via the motor driver and this output is controlled by the potentiometer on the front side from ~15VDC to ~25VDC. All these components are fixed easily in the empty part of the handle.

The joystick (above the power switch) is used to control the hight of the sonic trap and it is taken from an old Volvo car (700/900 series) where it was used for the power mirrors.

Modifications

Some modifications are needed for the components to fit inside the enclosure, like de-soldering all the PCB terminal blocks of the driver, adding just the wires. Also filling down the sides of the heat sink and edges of the PCB is necessary for it to fit.

Design aspects

This is my original drawing with inspiration taken from real pistol grips. The design is made to be strong and printer friendly, but requires some support for the bridges and steep slopes.

title: Z leadnut Bracket for Solyslva CNC

description.text:
Replacement Z bracket for Solsylva CNC.

My Z axis was being a bit screwy, so I decided to slightly upgrade from the hardware store all thread. These days you can buy a cheap leadscrew from amazon that comes with flanges, couplings and pillow bearings for less than I paid for just the coupling back when I built the machine. So decided to replace the all thread with a T8 300mm leadscrew.

The original bracket is screwed vertically into the wood between the Z rails, unfortunately trying to remove this pulled it right out. It's screwed into wood, that doesn't really go so well if you try to redo it. I also figured that because all the force is vertical, it made more sense to attach to this wood horizontally, as vertically all the forces were on the threads in the wood, which was already bad.

It's a drop in replacement, assuming you have a similarly sized leadscrew flange to the one I bought. If you want to use the horizontal screws (There are recesses for M3 nuts, so use M3 screws) you'll need to drill two holes through the wood bracket between the z rails. The hole is there if your original bolt is in place (the vertical one that attached the original bracket) you'll also need to drill holes to attach the Z flange, these don't print, as it seems the mounting holes vary.

Pics attached of my print and on the machine.

title: Schnabel-car for Märklin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
his model of a Schnabel - car is not based on a real prototype. It is an impressonate model which just show the typical shape of such a car and has a size to use on most regular layouts.
It uses the bogies used at the Märklin - cars 4617/4618. And the transformer-model which came with Märklin 4617.

Needed parts to complete the car:

Four bogies from Märklin 4617/4618 or other bogies with a 5mm hole. The couplers, buffers and the handrail must be removed from two (the inner) bogies.
Four 1.4x6 bolts and nuts or hard wire (1mm dia.) to mount the transformer-bridge to the arms.
Four M3 screws and 5mm washers to mount the bogies to the bogie-bridge.

To assemble one car you need to print two bogie-bridges (either with or without cab), two arms, one transformer-bridge, one or two roofs for the cab and four bogie - bolts. The bogie-bolts have M3 threads and must be glued to the bogie-bridges.

The sample model shown is finished with filler, partly sanded and sprayed in the red color of the German Railways.

author: Retro_Emulation

description.text:
https://youtu.be/FjvrO9ZWBQU
This minirobot has two small geared motors and is brought alive by an ATtiny85 and a simple sketch:

int R = 0; //right motor
int L = 1; //leftr motor
void setup()
{ pinMode(R, OUTPUT); pinMode(L, OUTPUT); }
void loop(){
//forward
digitalWrite(R, HIGH); digitalWrite(L, HIGH); delay(1000);
//around left wheel
digitalWrite(R, HIGH); digitalWrite(L, LOW); delay(84);
//forward
digitalWrite(R, HIGH);
digitalWrite(L, HIGH); delay(1000);
// around right wheel
digitalWrite(R, LOW); digitalWrite(L, HIGH); delay(84);
}

An O-ring around the two wheels gives better grip. The third wheel is just a M3 bolt with a rounded nut.
The frog is decoration and can be found on Thigiverse.

description.text:
This is a cup holder system I designed to hold Yeti or generic cups in our SxS. The bracket will hold all the different cup holders as we go through the day starting with the coffee mug and ending with the smallest cup. Gravity holds the holders in the bracket. If you end up tipping over, well the cup holder that fell out is probably the least of your worries. You can put some small felt sticky feet in the mug holder to prevent rattling from removing the finish on the cup and it fits snug. I haven't tried it on the rest.

I uploaded new cup holder files. They print fine now. Most of the issue was my slicer. The original files should work as well. These just have lessons learned incorporated as I figured out better ways to accomplish the same task. I will post new pictures after I gather all my Yeti's to pose with them!

description.text:
Keypad using mechanical keys, Arduino Pro Micro &ILI9340 SPI Display

Input device to improve workflow and user input without having to remember a lot of different key combinations.

Hardware

Mechanical Keys: http://r.ebay.com/ffwsff
Microcontroller: Arduino Pro Micro (Ebay - different models available)
Display: http://r.ebay.com/y8ZTcp

Software
The software running on the Arduino uses the OneButton Library [https://github.com/mathertel/OneButton] to simply connect multiple buttons without debounce handling needed.
At the moment the software allows multiple modes (window management, start of programms and input of special characters)
The display shows the current selected mode and the function of the keys.

On the computer side i use autohotkey for the command handling. [autohotkey.com]

Code will follow soon.

WIRING
The wiring depends on the microcontroller you use and the display. For my current configuration I connected the display to the spec sheet. Its a simple SPI connection. The reset pin is always pulled high.

The buttons are connected to one digital pin each, using the internal pullup resistor. The other pin of the mechanical button is connected to ground. Pressing the button grounds the pin. This allows a design without other resistors only using the arduino microcontroller.

Work in progress!

building:

sand the brass edges
sold a wire to the brass, near the big center hole in the mounting
thread the wire through the handle
screw the brass stripes to the probe body
wire the center pole to one pole form your estim device
wire the left and the right pole together to the other pole form your device

CAUITION: USE IT AT YOUR OWN RISK !
