title: QuickRelease for T500/T300 Steering Wheel base

description.text:
I wasn't happy with the quality of chinese QR for my simulator's steering wheel. A friend of mine showed me a design on Youtube (can't find the author now, sorry) so I decided to design it myself for my T500 universal adapter (the 70mm 6 holes standard).

You need a saddle quick-release clamp of 34mm for the actual fit mechanism. I recommend the hub (the female part) to be printed in ABS for more strength and near 100% of infill and a strong pattern (update: previously I was recommending 65% of infill, but that can be too low). The steering adapter (the male part) can be printed in PLA with similar infill if you like.

Both parts fit quite tight. The first attempts will require a bit of effort until the steering adapter gets some wear on the edges. There's also a bit of vacuum effect when you detach the steering from the hub. But once the pieces are fitted, there's no wobble at all (although it's made of plastic, so it won't be as stiff as a metal piece obviously). I've been using it for a month or so, and it works quite well to be honest, so I have decided to share with the community.

UPDATE: version 1.1 (22/01/2018)
My first hub broke while I was playing so I had to make some improvements. New version has more material for the surroundings of the hexagon and I used a fillet for better stress handling on the base. The male part is thinner but so far there is no evidence of weakness.
I would also suggest something with better layer adhesion than ABS like PETG. Or if you use ABS, make sure that the settings allow the best layer adhesion you can achieve.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

No

Notes:
  • ABS or PETG for the Hub as it has to withstand the pressure of the clamp.
    UPDATE: I would suggest using a stronger infill pattern (lines, grid, etc...) and nearly 100% of infill for peace of mind.
  • Steering adapter can be printed in PLA but I guess ABS will work better. (By the way, please rotate the piece to lay flat on the printer bed)
  • Screws are M5 and the length will depend on your base and steering wheel. In my case I had to use some extra nuts for my 35mm length screws.
  • You need a saddle quick release clamp of 34mm

title: Easy print & glue - Panzer V Panther Ausf.G
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When I startet printing vehicles I often was frustrated about the deficient print quality and the awful cleaning work.

So I decided to divide the object into several parts.
The focus is on print quality and avoiding support structures.
After printing, the parts have to be glued together.

Meanwhile I printed and built some models in this way.

I publish the print files for all users which like to have quick and good prints results.

I will start publishing the files under the title "Easy print & glue"

Finally let my thank the original designers of the models. They are important for our community. I only cut their models into several pieces ... nothing else.

This time I worked on the Panzer V Panther Ausf.G.
David Drysdale offers a more detailed resin printer version.
I took this object, cutted it into several pieces and printed it with my FDM printer at a scale of 1/72.
The details, especially the tracks, turned out great.

The 3 parts of the hull, front, middle and rear section were printed without support.
The slewing ring and the hatches of the turret were also printed without support.
The tracks and the turret were printed with support.

description.text: was looking for a hardpoint for mounting my fpv antenna in an Eflite Opterra or any foam plane. The idea is to apply hot glue and press into the foam then drill out the center. The center is 6.7mm which is just wide enough for a tight fit for the sma extension from the vtx. then you can screw the nut on the extension and it is hard mounted. I first printed it in PLA and then tried PETG for the first time- the initial design had the teeth breaking off very easily, so I modified the design with .5mm thicker teeth.. they still broke so I obviously had something else wrong- I printed with my PLA settings. Had a quick look on the internet and realized that I needed to turn off my layer cooling fan and the next one came out strong. I could probably go back to the original design and be fine with PLA, but uploaded them both anyway

Use this file is to create a frame for the driven, reflector, and parasitic elements of a biquad yagi of your own specifications. The default values are for a 2.4 GHz antenna with a centre frequency of 2.442 GHz (centre of WiFi channels), but can be made resonant at just about any frequency, with as many elements as you wish.

Updates:

  • 2018 Jan 7
    • Initial upload with basic frame.

  • 2018 Jan 8
    • Added optional configurable holes for antenna boom.
    • Some code/math cleanup.

  • 2018 Jan 11
    • Added optional frame support fillet.

  • 2018 Jan 16
    • Added boom tubes.
    • Corrected console reporting of reflector element length.
    • Removed "work in progress" status.

  • 2018 Jan 20
    • Added optional mounting hole in boom tube.

To Do:

  • Maybe chamfer some edges... Maybe.

  • Code/math cleanup.

  • Make a "how to" write up.

Use OpenSCAD to open the biquad yagi generator file.

For a ready-to-print 2.4 GHz antenna with boom tubes, check out the 2.4 GHz Biquad Yagi Antenna.



I don't design antennas professionally, nor do I have any formal education in antenna theory and design. This file takes as many variables in to account as I could think of to allow you to create an antenna the way you want it.

description.text:
Amsterdam Canalbridge

This model of a (Dutch) Amsterdam Canalbridge is inspired by the drawbridges in Amsterdam and is part of the “New Amsterdam Crochet Project”, that my wife has initiated.

Many more 3D printed models were the result of this project (I will upload those soon). I have included a few pictures of the entire New Amsterdam crochet scene (by night), to get an idea of the project this model is part of.

When fully assembled this drawbridge model will be 25 cm long, 22 cm wide, 19 cm high.
This bridge fits well into the LGB model train scale (approx. 1:25).

NOTE: All parts can be printed without the use of support material.

Parts list -> number of times to print:

BRIDGE_MAIN_TRUSS.STL-> 1 piece
FLOOR.STL-> 1 piece
BRIDGE_CROWN.STL-> 1 piece
BRIDGE_ARM+COUNTERWEIGHT.STL-> 1 piece
BRIDGE_RAMP.STL -> 1 piece
RAILING_BRACE.STL-> 2 pieces
FENCE_RIGHT.STL-> 1 piece
FENCE_LEFT.STL-> 1 pieces
RAILING.STL -> 4 pieces

Additional materials:

M3x10 bolt: 4 pieces - Used as hinges - connecting the 2 rail-braces to the 4 railings
M3x10 bolt: 4 pieces - Used as hinges - connecting the 2 rails with the main truss
M3x25 bolt: 2 pieces - Used as hinges - connecting the floor part with the ramp part
M3x20 bolt: 2 pieces - Used as hinges - connecting the arm part to the “crown” part 2

Miniature metal chain (as used in jewelry) – to hang the floor (road) part onto the arm
part. Also, another piece of this chain has been used to pull down the counterweight (and thus raise the bridge).

Happy printing!
Huib Schippers (Tinkerman)

description.text:
This is a drilling jig that is intended to help guide drill holes for adding tungsten weights to the bottom of a pinewood derby car. The default settings are setup for 3/8" diameter weights, and distributing the holes on either side of the shorter of the two axel lengths on the block. You can use the tool to drill 1 or 3 holes in front of the axel and optionally do the same behind if more weight is needed. On my son's car we did 3 in front and 1 behind.

Use the slot to ensure alignment to the axel channel on your block, then clamp it to the body. Add tape to your drill bit once you've determined the depth you need (for the number of weights you are adding, and the depth of the jig).

If you want to flip your car backwards or custom, you can change the axelDistFromRear to the measurement you want.

title: Smart Effector layer fan mount & duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 2018/02/10: Added two more duct sections - one for 5mm OD aluminium tubes and one for 6mm OD tubes

This set of parts is designed to fit the DC42 Smart Effector. It uses a 40x15 blower fan and uses the 'tusk' approach.

There are 4 components to this set:

  • the duct that the tusks fit into. Two versions are supplied - one has a ridge to aid seating into the collar. I use the version without this collar but you may choose to use the version with the rim
  • a collar that is glued to the fan outlet
  • a mount that is attached under the board using two of the magnet ball joint screws

In addition, you will need:

  • 12 3mm x 3mm (or 4mm) neodymium magnets to hold the duct to the collar
  • some 4mm OD aluminium tube for the tusks

The tusks are crimped closed at one end. Some people prefer to make a series of small holes for air exit but I'm trying slots that I cut with a cutting disc in my Dremel.

The tusks are not glued in, friction holds them in place and allows them to be rotated to direct the air where desired.

Other parts designed for my printers include:

description.text:
I needed a finger screw with a surface that had a good grip.
I had some cariage bolts with a square-neck, that I thought would give a nice finish, when pressed into the recess in the finger screw. I made this for a M6x1mm bolt that has a head diameter of approx. 15 mm.

The bolt head is pressed into the recess the first time you tighten the finger screw.
It was a tight fit on the screw I used, but I had no problem drawing the head into the knob, thanks to the good finger grip.

I designed this in Fusion 360, simply by creating a cylinder and adding a chamfer to the top and bottom. Then I used the coil feature to create a triangular cutout on a 45 degree revolution. Mirroring this cutout and finally generating a circular pattern of the 2 cutouts, gave the wanted knurled surface. Finally I made the recess, square cutout and hole.

description.text:
This is a print-in-place case for the Sphero Mini. It has space to carry all the parts from the toy, including the bowling pins and charge cable. It also allows charging of the Sphero with the case closed. The two halves of the Sphero shell sit along the sides of the case, so that you can see the logo on each side. It also allows you to see the charging glow while it's plugged in, shining through the shell. The shell halves fit in specific slots, with one being slightly larger than the other.

I made the clasp thicker to prevent it from breaking along the lamination layers, so it doesn't flex to open or close. It may require some sanding to get the right amount of clearance to close but still remain easy enough to open without excessive force.

I've found it easiest to plug the Sphero in with the USB cable before closing the lid, rather than trying to plug it in while the case is closed. It rolls around freely inside the case, making it tough to orient otherwise.

title: E3D V6 Mount for GeeeTech Prusa i3 Pro X
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Because i did not find any mount for an E3D V6 (direct drive) for my GeeeTech Prusa i3 Pro X, i designed my own one.

Design goals:

  • Mount should fit on the existing X carriage.
  • As many old parts as possible should be reused.
  • The loss in Z height should be as small as possible
  • The outer shape of Part i3B1-30 should be kept to be able to mount existing stuff.
  • As KISS as possible

Notes:

  • a fan mount is available here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2763717
  • used https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:341689 for the hotend model
  • The loss in Z height is (only) about 15 mm.
  • Mounting the new design is painful, because space is tight and several screws of the Part i3B1-29 are placed suboptimal.
  • With a redesigned part i3B1-29 both problems could be solved.
  • Slightly lighter than the original hot end (about 11 grams)

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20-30%

Cleaning

Strip off excessive material with a sharp knife. (Mostly where the parts were sitting on the plate)

Parts needed

Additionally to some of the existing screws, square nuts and washers of the old assembly you will need the following parts:

  • 2 x 16 mm screws, 2 hex nuts
  • 2 x 20 mm screws
  • 2 x 30 mm screws, 2 washers, 2 hex nuts

title: 2 to 1 Waste Water Pipe (washing machine and dishwasher outlets)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I recently obtained a dishwasher, but the problem was i had was only one outlet Pipe (not connected under sink) for waste water from washing machine and dishwasher and i could not fit them both in, so made a simple design to allow two waste water pipes to fit the one pipe.

Tested to fit a 4cm standard pipe, no leaks (after 5 attempts) but i have not tested running both outlets at the same time as this might be to much water to handle.

Feel free to use, and if anyone tests the two outlets together, please leave a comment saying so, and if it fails, will look at a re design.

Note: STL slight variation to pictures shown after testing.

20%? (might differ by 5%)

Sliced using Cura 3.1.0, Added raft as first attempt curled of bed (no heated bed), res was at 0.3, first layer 0.3. Also set perimeters to 3 to allow solid walls, without infill. although infill was set to 20% for the center pipe (may wish to increase to 25% after printing)

I printed two ends down first (flip stl 180), due to print bed size, but I think slicing whatever way you feel comfortable with should be fine. but this way also reduces support needed.

Print your own fancy gear clock!

I made this design actually because of an 'accident', I was working on a project where I needed to print gears. One gear I printed way too big and when I came back to check the print it was already half way done so I let it finish and designed some numbers to turn the gear into a clock! :D

mettre quelque support pour les pièces du couvert

This is a version of the Tea Gallows (see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2630698) working with an Attiny84 on a onesided PCB made with Eagle. There are three printed parts which are different:

bottom_PCB.stl, top_PCB.stl, panel_PCB.stl, knob.stl

The necessary Eagle-file for making a PCB is "tea_gallows_attiny84.brd"

The bascom-file for programming the Attiny84 is "tea_gallows_attiny84.bin"

You need the following electronical parts for the PCB:

(Programming adaptor for the Attiny84)

ATTINY 84A-PU: Atmel AVR 8-bit 8 KB, DIP-14

R1 – R9: protective resistor, 150 Ohm, SMD Size 0805

Led1 – 8: 3mm, normal LEDs without internal resistor

Ceramic capacitor: 100nF, SMD Size 0805

Tactile switch: length of the actuator: ~6mm, such as (https://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/tactile-switches/4791435/)

Photomos Relais: Panasonic, AQY212S (https://www.buerklin.com/de/photomos-relais/p/29g8781)

Buzzer: KPX-G1203B-6400 (https://www.voelkner.de/products/209749/Magnetischer-Summer-Kpx-G1203b-6400.html)

Molex pin header (Battery connector) — SMD — Pico Blade — 1 x 2-pin — connector: 1 piece, MOLEX 532610271 (https://www.reichelt.com/us/en/Molex-multiple-connector/MOLEX-532610271/3/index.html?ACTION=3&LA=3&ARTICLE=186225&GROUPID=7981)

Molex pin header (Servo connector) — SMD — PicoBlade — 1 x 3-pin — connector: 1 piece, MOLEX 533980371 (https://www.reichelt.com/us/en/Molex-multiple-connector/MOLEX-532610371/3/index.html?ACTION=3&LA=517&ARTICLE=186227&GROUPID=7981&trstct=lsbght_sldr::186225)

Molex crimp contact (for the battery connector) — PicoBlade — socket: 2 piece, MOLEX 500798100 (https://www.reichelt.com/us/en/Molex-multiple-connector/MOLEX-500798100/3/index.html?ACTION=3&LA=446&ARTICLE=186235&GROUPID=7981&artnr=MOLEX+500798100&SEARCH=MOLEX%2B500798100%2B%253A%253A%2BMolex%2Bcrimp%2Bcontact%2B%25C2%2597%2BPicoBlade%2B%25C2%2597%2Bsocket)

Molex crimp housing (for the battery connector) — PicoBlade — 1x 2-pin — socket: 1 piece, MOLEX 510210200 (https://www.reichelt.com/us/en/Molex-multiple-connector/MOLEX-510210200/3/index.html?ACTION=3&LA=446&ARTICLE=186197&GROUPID=7981&artnr=MOLEX+510210200&SEARCH=
MOLEX%2B510210200%2B%253A%253A%2BMolex%2Bcrimp%2Bhousing%2B%25C2%2597%2BPicoBlade%2B%25C2%2597%2B1x%2B2-pin%2B%25C2%2597%2Bsocket)

Battery contacts: Plate size: 20 x 12mm (https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00PZT080S/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

First you have to set the fuses as described here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2630698
Flash the memory with tea_gallows_attiny84.bin. Since we need the Port B3 as digital output (Reset-Pin!) you have finally to disable external reset in the fuses. This means, afterwards you have no access to the µC anymore. Only a H(igh)V(oltage)-programmer can bring it back to factory settings and make it programmable again!!! Good luck!
The ceramic capacitor is neither seen on the schedule nor on the board. You solder it between the legs of Pin 1 and Pin 14 (see photo)
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dTPM5exy1T9

title: GameClip for encased Sony Xperia Z3 (source files included)

description.text:
This is a model based on bernabap's GameClip. It holds my encased Sony Xperia Z3 (74mm wide, 10mm thick) to the PS3 controller (Dualshock 3). I placed the phone over the controller for a better center of gravity so it takes less effort to hold.

Expert Cura users only: I also included two volumes for more detailed infill and excluding support. For this you need the per-model-settings and mesh features in Cura v3.1.0+. You can use them to remove all supports where you most certainly don't need them (anti overhang mesh) and increase the infill at the weak spot around the Home Button (infill mesh; I recommend overall infill of ~25% with 2 walls and 90% infill for the infill mesh). Just merge the objects when you applied all settings.

CAD users: I uploaded the .step file as well so you can resize the clip for YOUR phone easily.

This is licensed under the GNU GPL v2. There is no warranty.

title: Small Qi charger with Apple Logo

description.text:
An Apple-branded cover for a small Qi charger that I bought here:

Qi Charger, 7 euro from allekabels.nl : https://www.allekabels.nl/draadloos-opladen/11543/1350614/qi-oplader-700-ma.html

The little charger is entirely embedded INSIDE the print. There are two ways to do this, please check under Print Settings. There are gaps for the (micro USB) power plug and for the status LED (blue when charging, red when no phone placed or not positioned correctly).

Printer:

DaVinci 1.0 Repetier

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed this in PLA at 100% infill - the model does not have much 'body', so the difference in filament used compared to lower infill levels is not very large. I chose the solid infill so that the 'lid' of the charger sticks well to the outer perimeters.

Because here is how you print this. You start printing normally, up to 15.90 mm. Then you pause the print! You drop the charger disc in the model, making sure the power opening is properly aligned with the big hole in the side. The status LED then automatically lines up with the smaller hole. You then resume printing and the printer 'buries' the charger under a solid layer of filament. It's quite cool to see this happen!

There are several ways to pause the printer. Some printers have a button for it, or if you use OctoPrint on Raspberry Pi (like I do), you can press pause on that. I actually used another OctoPrint feature, which is that is pauses the print when it finds the gcode M0. I inserted the following lines after layer 78 (= after 15.90 mm):

; MANUAL_EDIT
; Pause to insert charger
G28 X ; home X
G28 Y ; home Y
M0 ; pause

Look in the provided gcode file and look for the MANUAL_EDIT comment line.

I actually paused the printer a second time, to change filament colour. My printer only has one extruder and I wanted to print the Apple logo in a different colour, like you see in the picture. This is of course optional, but if you want to do this, pause again after layer 86.

description.text:
A fractal-based volumetric object. Available in the following versions:
RAW data 400x400x400 8-bit (zipped)
PNG codec AVI 400x400x400
PLY isosurface mesh 2.5M polygons
STL isosurface mesh (smoothed, reduced) 500K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects.
Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here:
40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371
Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here:

author: 3dintaitung

description.text:
Hey! I made this to properly swing my Centripro around me. It's based on a keychain ring, a screw with 15mm head, a washer and a trapped nut.

What you need:

  • Keychain ring (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2016-Hot-Sale-50-pcs-Set-Stainless-Steel-Silver-15mm-Keychain-Split-Key-Ring-Loop/32787905351.html)
  • Washer (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/100pcs-M3-DIN9021-304-A2-Stainless-Steel-Large-Size-Flat-Washer-hw138/32733354801.html)
  • M5 Nut (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/M5-Nuts-Hex-Stainless-Steel-Silver-Metric-Pitch-0-8mm-DIN934-Pack-100/32777523248.html)
  • M5 Screw with min 15mm head (I used old Ikea high sleeper screws)

You need to pause the print at a certain height. Google for "pause at height" and add it to your post processing option in cura / slic3r. You should do test prints and test your real dimensions. I used a 0.6mm nozzle for this print and had to widen the sizes.

If the print is finished, clean the hole and insert the screw. It should slightly grip into the material. Use it to center the washer and fix it with superglue. Make sure your screw is tight enough and won't wiggle or turn around, while swinging.

For the keychain ring I used shrink tubing and superglue to keep it in place.

author: PDTRob

description.text:
Wall mounted Cup-Holder for the bathroom

This model was specifically designed for the IKEA Reko glass cup.
Will of course work as well with any other tapered glass with a diameter of 63 mm.

Cup holder is mounted to the wall with two 4 mm screws for a solid connection.

author: GauR

description.text: My son received a Playstation VR for Christmas. We found the cable/cord on the camera frequently made it difficult to get the camera to stay pointed in the desired direction. In addition, we thought it might be beneficial to be able to better control the camera height. I designed and printed this clamp/mount that easily attaches to a tripod. In order to deal with tolerances, I used a 2mm rubber cord between the clamp and the camera. You can purchase the cord from Amazon. The pieces have a 2mm diameter 1mm deep grove cut into them. I pushed the cord into the groove and cut it to length. The clamp is designed to be 1.6mm larger in diameter than the camera body. The 2mm cord squishes and holds the camera in place without having to account for tolerances in the printer. The clamp has a threaded hole in the middle sized to standard tripod threads (1/4-20 UNC). The clamps tighten down with 4 M3x6mm screws.

There are some excellent fan ducts for the Printrbot - such as this one - that improve considerably on the default duct. However, every one I've used seems to suffer from the same problem, e.g. the fan is trying to push more air through the duct than it really can handle. Part of the problem is that the flow in to the fan is in no way helped by the shape of the fan and how it is mounted.

I decided to try a classic bell-mouth inlet and center body; this is a common strategy to improve flow for wind tunnels and other systems where efficiency and smooth flow are important.

My non-quantified observations (putting my fingers up next to the inlet; listening to the flow; feeling the airflow coming out of the duct by the extruder tip) indicate that using this inlet helps quite a bit!

Even if it didn't make any difference at all to the performance -- it makes your Printrbot look awesome :-)

You will need slightly longer M3 screws to attach the inlet to your fan. I tried to trim down the flange enough to work with the stock screws, but it ends up too thin.

To attach the inlet, the machine screws are left loose enough for the inlet to be put in place, and then rotated 45 deg into position with the screws in the slots. This technique allows the screws to be put in place through all the other hardware first.

The "spacer" is optional - it fills in a few mm gap between the bottom of the center body and the fan. If you use it, just glue it to the bottom of the upper inlet.

This is the plan to build the Tiny Whoov (very first of its kind ;)

The Tiny Whoov is a nano remote controled hoovercraft which uses the power and control system of a tiny whoop or blade inductrix like nano quads (fpv or not).

It's a very simple 1 hour build ! Just cut the different parts out of a 5 or 6mm foam sheet (depron or paperfoam) and glue them together with hot glue gun (following the letters and for positioning). Paint it and add the electronics with the glue gun as well. Please have a close look at the pictures to understand what motor goes where (it took me some time and tests to figure this out ;)

FEW TIPS FOR THE BUILD :

1) get the right positioning for the motors !!
BACK MOTORS OF THE QUAD = THRUST AND DIRECTION
FRONT MOTORS OF THE QUAD = LIFT (hover)

2) if you use inductrix/whoop propellers > they work much better and blowing air towards the motors (like they do on the micro quad). If you reverse, you will lost efficiency.

3) try to keep it as light as possible (under 50gr for best performances)

4) You can add a "skirt" made of a plastic bag to make it even better, but it works very well without it.

Please leave me a feedback or comments if you like it !

Can't wait to see what you guys will make with this...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-kZM0Icg0BY

https://youtu.be/6sUAy4ytuQw

Enjoy ! Alex (@badassdrones on instagram)

title: UDI U818A - Stand Alone - Camera Mount & Battery Storage

description.text:
I buy inland filament from Mircocenter. So I'm frequently at the Michigan store. My son and I bought the UDI U818A-1 quadcopter - drone there over a good year ago, and it has been the best quadcopter we ever owned. It has survived so many crashes and has not even broken once. .. We almost lost it the 1st night by taking it up 200 feet at night and the wind grabbed it. We battled the wind for 10 mins (in the low setting (should have had it in the high setting)), but If fell down from 200 ft after the battery gave out. We found it 30mins later on the side walk, on a street 2 blocks over from our street. ... LOL

So it is worth outfitting this quadcopter / drone with a FPV camera.
Yes it already has a camera at the bottom, but it's not FPV, and I didn't want to buy the UDI FPV version that has it. Side Note: Also with buying a seperate tiny whoop FPV camera, it can be re-purposed to be used on my son's RC Truck.

Also the cost to get into FPV racing is a bit steep, especially if you just want to try it to even see if you like it. So instead of buying new equipment, I simply designed/remixed a camera mount to hold a tiny whoop camera on the UDI U818A-1 quad.* Rubber bands hold it down well. My son has so much FUN!!!

The UDI U818A-1 quad is more than strong enough to fly with 2 batteries.... one for the camera, and one for drone. The drone's main battery is located at the bottom.

Original camera used was the Crazepony 5.8Gz Polarized Clover Leaf Antenna ($25), which fit this top mount the best. However, so how it is now missing (Ugh! It is so small it might have accidentally been thrown away; I hope we find it).

The FPV camera in the pictures is the Wolfwhoop WT05 Micro AIO ($17), so the top piece had to be mirrored to accommodate the camera wires (I had to trim at the back too, see pictures). This camera has a wider angle view of 140 degrees (Note: The Crazepony had 120 degree view). But the clover antenna is suppose to get a longer range.

The FPV viewer my son received for Christmas was the Eachine EV800 ($90). Works great!

End result... a fun drone that my son can fly around the house. He sits in the basement, and flies it up to the 2nd floor where the bedrooms are with no issues.

*Note: I'm not the original designer of the camera mount on the top piece ... See 30 x 30 Top mount tx03 cam universal ... # 2192570.

title: LED Lamps for Original Prusa i3

description.text:
I designed these lightweight heads for my Prusa i3Mk2S to provide a broad cast of light in the front and back. They are designed so that you can have light in the front, the back, or both as the light standards are independant. Small gauge wiring will run through the inside of the light standards and out the mount. There are some utility hooks on the mounts for cable management. I made the lamp heads to accommodate 12VDC LED automobile dome lights (see photo).

Only use supports manually placed underneath the dome. DO NOT put supports inside the tubes or you will have a heck of time getting them out. With good bridge settings, you should have no troubles. I printed mine in PETG and used high temp hot glue to hold the lamps in the heads (CA glue will also work). All parts are held together with CA glue.

I made the joints very snug, so a bit of sanding or slight tweaking with a scalpel may be required for the best fit. I suggest you do a dry fit first, take apart, run wiring through and solder it up, then glue and assemble. Make sure you have the gantry mounts oriented correctly for your application, they should attach from the back side or they will interfere with the X-axis at maximum Z-height.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3Mk2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Only place supports under the light dome.

Use nice wide brim of at least 8mm to hold light standards to bed as they may lift.

Assembly
  1. Dry fit and adjust
  2. Disassemble
  3. Run wiring and solder light
  4. Reassemble and glue with CA
  5. Use high-temp hot glue, epoxy or thick CA to glue in LEDs

title: Makita power for your Millwaukee heated gear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have Makita tools 18v but I wanted a Milwaukee heated hoodie or vest
so I look around Milwaukee has a 18v power adapter to run the heated gear from 18v Millwaukee batteries a little poking around and some help from friends at my local tool store
I got enough info

ok now the warning
this is a personal project if you chose to copy it you take all risks what ever they maybe and accept that this will probably void any and all warranties may or may not burn your house down or make your Brand X tool owner friends hate you I am not responsible for any damages this thing or the use of this thing causes.

first we need a jack to fit the plug on the hoodie
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5Pcs-3A-12v-for-DC-Power-Supply-Jack-Socket-Female-Panel-Mount-Connector-5-5mm-2/32599220409.html?spm=a2g0s.13010208.99999999.262.BEmM73

now we did some digging foung the unloaded voltage of Genuine Milwaukee adapter is about 15.3 volts so we need a dc to dc buck converter
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5PCS-XM1584-Ultra-small-size-DC-DC-step-down-power-supply-module-3A-adjustable-step-down/32531438467.html?spm=a2g0s.13010208.99999999.276.BEmM73
I would set this somewhere above 12v but below 14v to be safe
and just becasue Milaukee did it we will add a usb port
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Fine-6-24V-12V-24V-to-5V-3A-CAR-USB-Charger-Module-DC-Buck-step-down/32811446277.html?spm=a2g0s.13010208.99999999.283.BEmM73

now again from what I have read and seen looking at theses jackets this should also power the dewalt and maybe the bosh and possibly the snap on as well your mileage may vary. you might need a different plug or a different voltage setting but Really if you think about it this will let you run pretty well any small electronic device from a Makita battery say you need to put a router or something on battery power for a few hours pretty well anything that need 5-18v under 2a could be run from this

This is a work in progress my parts are on the way if anyone prints this before I do or has any good ideas let me know I am working on a low voltage cut off circuit to protect the batteries

comments.text:

I've been told by Milwaukee customer support that the jackets don't work very well with 18v systems not even with their own 18v systems.
I have a Milwaukee jacket and I ended buying a 6A battery for it.
Anyways, good luck with your project.
Keep us posted.

title: Petrichorwa Massage Table Adjustable Headrest Arm

description.text: The original headrest arm failed along the shaft during normal use. This design inserts a 3/8" threaded rod into the shaft to reinforce the arm. Except for the threaded rod, the part was cloned and printed using PTEG filament.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

80%

Notes:

Use PTEG or stronger material.

Tap each piece using a 3/8" x 16 tap to a depth of 1.5" minimum. Thread the rod into the splined piece first insuring the rod is screwed into the main cylinder portion. The whole in each part is sized properly for the tap and should not require any reaming.

Don't be concerned about the tap depth not going all the way into each part. The shaft will cut its way into the parts once started in the tapped area. You may need to install two jamb nuts on the end of the shaft and use a socket or other appropriate tool to thread the shaft into the splines part. The handle should be able to be threaded on to the shaft without the use of tools.

Construction

I duplicated the original part to insure the replacement would mate to the Bed. This involved duplicating a 46 element spline that allowed the user to adjust the headrest angle as well as the shift which fits into the headrest itself.

The new part was divided into two sections that allowed a 3/8" threaded shaft to be screwed into both pieces thus reinforcing the resulting assembly at the critical stress points.

The splinted piece was printed with the splines up while the arm was printer vertically.

author: jmillerfo

description.text: This is a test of what I call Macro Foam. It uses the capabilities for 3D printing to produce accurate arrangements of multiple materials to create a digital composite, and demonstrates a procedurally generated example. This material was intended to have specifically controllable properties of density and compressibility (once the materials are calibrated through testing). It is made of a solid material, a soft, elastic material, and empty space. The idea (totally untested) is that the material would be low-density and very compressible until the hard parts come in contact with each other, at which point the resistance quickly increases. The "foam" is generated by a novel combination of classical algorithms. It first places seed points within the volume. These points are randomly distributed here, but could easily vary in density and arrangement based on the results of a simulation, increasing density based on stress, for example. To generate the spheres, each voxel is colored based on the distance to the nearest seed point, resulting in spherical gradients. The connecting components are given by the voronoi diagram of this same set of points. By multiplying adjusted versions of the two complementary data sets together and generating a surface based on a threshold, a model is created consisting of spheres (solid material) separated by connecting elements (soft material). The input for this test is given in my 3D Texture Objects in these Thingiverse pages: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27231 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27232 The STL's here have had partial structures at the edges trimmed out to show the area of interest. I've provided the AVI volumes and heavily reduced versions of the meshes suitable for visualization.

Ideally this type of model would be printed on an Objet, but very soft PLA would work for the soft spots. All parts could be printed hollow to create the lowest overall density. Assuming the spheres and supports are solid, the material is about 22% solid material, 16% soft material, and 62% empty space. This model uses very large elements because of the limitations of working with polygons, and the reproducible detail on FDM/FFM machines. I will upload a high-res version with finer features soon. 
This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects.
Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here:
40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371
Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here:
engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

description.text: This follow-focus speed crank works fantastic! Make sure to CA glue the knob to the handleshaft. There is a print-in-place ball bearing inside the crank lug. I recommend printing the threaded handleshaft vertically using a super wide brim. Also print the knob vertical with the opening on the bed with a super wide brim. I would also recommend using a bit of light lubricant when threading in the shaft to the lug as it is a snug fit. Print the crankshaft horizontally as it is in the file. Use a raft and supports. This will be the strongest orientation and allow the ballbearing and threads to work well.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Quick picatinny rail mount for Winchester 94AE (chambered in 357 Magnum). Note this must be the AE version, or a version drilled and tapped in the same way, as the mount uses the screw holes above the chamber.

The mount is made up of 3 parts;

  • A sight plate that fits into the dovetail that the buckhorn sight originally fitted into.
  • A mount that fits onto the sight plate and wraps around the barrel.
  • A section of picatinny rail that fits on top of the mount.

I've included a 2 piece version as well, with the mount and the rail as one piece. This requires printing with supports, and a lot more cleanup. As such I would heavily suggest just using the 3 piece version which is super easy to print.

Installation Instructions:

  • Remove buckhorn sight by drifting it to the right with a rubber hammer and punch.
  • Install 2 M3 threaded inserts into the sight plate (I use
    https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/262993790868).
  • Insert the sight plate into the dovetail that the buckhorn sight originally fitted into.
  • Place mount on top so that sight plate fits into the cutout.
  • Place rail on top of the mount and secure in place using; 2 M3 screws through the holes in the mount into the sight plate; 2 M3.5 screws through the holes in the mount into the screw holes above the chamber (I just reused the ones that came with the gun originally).

description.text:
A well thought-out 3D design for the fans of Experty. Fully print friendly made and can be used as a keychain for example.

Experty mission is to encourage the adoption of cryptocurrency on a global scale by creating an intuitive, easy to use application that is suitable for wide scale usage. We expect mass adoption within the next 3 years. Anyone who needs to make a consultation via the Experty app will also have a cryptocurrency wallet in their pocket.

Experty current focus is on solving the talent crisis in the blockchain community by allowing experts to monetize their skills through a skype-like voice and video application. Payments are handled through an automated smart contract system using Experty’s native token EXY. This will let companies obtain the talent they need, allowing the blockchain community to continue to expand and flourish.

Check the website for more information about this project: https://experty.io/en

title: VR Stand Extension for Oculus Touch

description.text:
This an extension for a VR stand (in Germany sold as PIRANHA, in Asia from TopAce, and in other countries with other brands), which allows to put both Oculus Touch controllers on the stand. You need to print two Oculus Touch Cradles by ClassicGOD as well, which you can screw to the extension. One of them you have to print out flipped horizontally. I used a normal screw 3x12mm to fix them to the middle-piece.
BTW, I also cut the stirrup so that the Oculus Rift glasses fits on it.

title: FLSUN i3 (2017) Marlin Auto Leveling Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: I've included a text-file that makes it easier to search and replace the specific values. Use "Ctrl+F" in Arduino IDE or whatever text editor you're using.

Quick guide on how to configure Marlin for automatic bed leveling using an inductive probe

Bed leveling type: bilinear (use linear if your surface is flat)
Probe Used: SN08-N

Please note: all the nozzle and probing offsets need to be adjusted according to your printers specifications. This is simply intended as a reference if you're setting up your own Configuration.h for the first time.

For further reference use Marlin's official documentation:
http://marlinfw.org/docs/configuration/configuration.html#bed-leveling
M851 - Z Probe Offset
http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M851.html

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RowhvQuRxOs

Simple&Safe; Marlin Update Workflow

Use a text comparison software and load your previous (working) Configuration.h and the new one side by side.

Adjust all the values that need to be changed. Done in less than 5 minutes. You'll never need to ask for a configuration.h again.

My text editor of choice is Notepad++ with the compare plug-in (https://sourceforge.net/projects/npp-compare)

description.text:
I've been watching for a model of the Orville for some time, and nothing has shown up, so I'm making this available for those out there who want a starting point.

The stl is the OnShape version, the other files are the LightWave version, done using what I learned making the other one.

Heres a 43 tooth wheel pulley (9mm can probably make wider if needed). No supports, and PLA works well. I designed this for my surf rods RKP trucks and they fit perfectly. They are made to use an integrated bearing so they need longer axle trucks.

Needs
-60g filament
-6 m3x20mm screws
-skate bearing

Just a basic replacement part for the receiver part of the Barska 20-60x60 spotting scope. The tripod mount attaches to this part.
The plastic that the 2 screws that hold this piece to the scope sat on was only 2mm thick and broke on my wife's scope. So I made a (very) basic replacement. Much thicker, the plastic that the screws use is now 3mm.
I used the original brass nut. Cracked the old piece to get the nut out, but just used a soldering iron to set the nut in the replacement.
Not the fanciest (just used tinkercad), but it's working...

Heres a 12mm wide HDT 5m wheel pulley for Abec 11 Flywheels. This was originally designed for Evolve supercarve trucks so a 10x22mm bearing fits perfectly in this.

Needs
-50g filament
-6 m3x20mm screws
-bearing
example art river

description.text:
Das (kleine) Rhombenkuboktaeder ist ein Polyeder (Vielflächner), das zu den archimedischen Körpern zählt. Es setzt sich aus 8 gleichseitigen Dreiecken und 18 Quadraten zusammen. Dabei bilden jeweils drei Quadrate und ein Dreieck eine Raumecke.

Jeweils 8 Kanten des Rhombenkuboktaeders bilden die Kanten eines regelmäßigen Achtecks. Insgesamt gibt es sechs solcher unabhängiger, gleichseitiger Achtecke in diesem Polyeder.

Der Name des Rhombenkuboktaeders beruht u. a. auf der Tatsache, dass 12 der 18 Quadrate deckungsgleich zu den 12 Rhomben eines umbeschriebenen Rhombendodekaeders sind. Der zum Rhombenkuboktaeder duale Körper ist das Deltoidalikositetraeder.

Tiny LED keychain to save you in that dark situations! Just attach it to your keys and you are ready to go! To add an extra brightness, I decided to use 2 LEDs. It uses one CR2032 battery, that can be easily changed just by pushing in the bottom hole with a paperclip. By doing that, the button will detach from the keychain, allowing you to change the battery.

Read building instructions!

To build this thing, you just have to insert the LEDs with the anode on the top and the cathode touching the bottom of the case.

Then, insert the battery between the anode and the cathode with the positive face upwards, and glue the cover to the case.

The button does not have to be glued, otherwise, you won't be able to change the battery. Maybe you will need to sand a bit the outline of the button to fit in the gap. Do not sand it too much or it won't stay in place.

title: Pliers - Self Opening
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Overview:

What kind of pliers do you use in math class? Answer: Multipliers!

These pliers are designed to be easy to print, moderately strong and they have built-in springs to self open when you release pressure on the handles.

Included are four variations:
A - Needle nose with jaw teeth
B - Needle nose with smooth jaws (no teeth)
C - Blunt nose with jaw teeth
D - Blunt nose with smooth jaws

Each pliers consists of two parts - a male and female side.

Supports:

The needle nose variations (types A and B) need supports. Supports are only needed under the nose section of the male part.

The blunt nose variations (types C and D) do not need any supports.

Assembly:

(1) Align the hinge notches of the two parts and press them together (sightly rotating back and forth can help find the right alignment). For reference the notches align in almost the fully opened position.

(2) After the parts are pressed together rotate the parts back and forth until the movement is smooth.

(3) For best results disassemble the parts and add a small amount of 3-in-1 oil to the hinge area and reassemble.

Design Motivation:

I normally clean the nozzle after loading filament or right before printing with a pair of pliers. After a few months I realized I had wore down the side of my brass nozzle because the pliers were made of hardened steel. So I looked around for a good pair of pliers to print. I had two requirements: (1) they self open and (2) they were the needle nose variety to help me reach the nozzle easier. I looked around and didn't find any models I liked so I decided to design my own.

Materials:

PLA, High Temp PLA, PETG

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Supports needed for the needle nose variations (types A and B) but not for the blunt nose pliers (types C and D)
